review_title: From a value perspective, this might be the best Roku yet...
review_text: I'm a long-time Roku user, having purchased devices from every generation throughout Roku's evolution. I've had the very original Roku N1100, Roku 2 XD, Roku 2 XS, Roku 3 (2013 version), Roku 4, a TCL Roku TV, Roku Ultra (2016 version)...and now this Stick +. While I've only had it for a couple of days now, this might be the best Roku I've seen from a value perspective.My house is a Roku house. We have 5 televisions but don't have a cable or satellite subscription.. One of the TV's is a Roku TV and the other 4 all have a Roku attached to them. Literally everything we watch is delivered via the Roku. Our OTA material is delivered from a Tablo DVR to our Rokus. Our local media is served up via a Plex server to the Rokus. We also have PS Vue, Netflix, Amazon video, etc. etc. Bottom line, we use Roku a lot, and I'm very familiar with them. I wouldn't consider myself to be a Roku "fan boy", though. While most of the Roku's I've had have been great...there have been some clunkers. The Roku 2XS was a turd that never got any better. The Roku 4 was a turd at the start, but gradually got better with each subsequent firmware update. Unfortunately, the cooling fan in one of my Roku 4s (The 4 was the only Roku model to ever have one) has begun to make the dreaded "grinding" noise in recent weeks, so I decided to try replace it with a stick+.I've generally been leery about all of the "stick" form-factor devices. They've generally lagged behind the more traditional "box" form-factor devices as far as specs go. The Stick+, with its quad-core processor, HEVC support, and 4K capabilities convinced me that the gap may have finally been closed.So, after a couple of days with the Stick+...here are my thoughts on this device- It's snappy and smooth. It's maybe not quite as quick as my Roku Ultras...but it's every bit as fast as the Roku 4.- The new remote is great.The ability to control the TV's power and volume without a second remote or a universal remote is loooong overdue.- Excellent wireless reception. I had two walls between the Stick+ and my router, but was easily streaming 16mbps local media through Plex.- Powering via the TV's USB isn't optimal. Assuming your TV stops providing power to the USB when turned-off, the Stick+ will have to go through the boot-up sequence and then connect to your wireless before you can do anything with it each time you turn on your TV. This can take ~30 seconds. I highly recommend plugging it directly into an outlet using the provided adapter.So, this is a great Roku device. It doesn't have the same bells-and-whistles that my Roku Ultra's have...but then again, I also paid nearly twice as much for those. This Stick+ is much cheaper, provides basically the same UI/playback performance, and also has a remote that will make having to juggle your Roku and TV remotes a thing of the past. That's why I say, absent some deal-breaker that I haven't encountered yet, this is the best dollar-for-dollar Roku yet.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2017
author: K. Krueger

review_text: I purchased the Streaming Stick+ after having repeated difficulties and problems with the Amazon Fire TV Stick. The difference in quality between these two products is astounding. While the Fire TV Stick required constant reboots and had consistently poor network performance, the Roku has been flawless and completely without problems. The addition of 4K support is a huge bonus. I'm especially impressed with the connectivity. My room, where I'm using the device, is on a different floor, on the other side of the house from our router, but I've never had an issue with connectivity or performance.The menu/interface is a little outdated, but I'd gladly sacrifice a flashy menu for good performance. It's astounding to me what a bad product the Fire TV Stick was now that I've switched to Roku. I enjoy the wide selection of channels as well - every streaming service seems to be available through Roku. The voice functionality on the remote works well, and I like that I can turn my TV on and off with the Roku remote as well as adjust the volume. All in all it's an awesome product.

author: Andrew

review_title: READ BEFORE BUYING! Great Roku stick and a great price!!
review_text: ***Quick note before reading numerous reviews! I research everything immensely before I buy it and one HUGE discrepancy I noticed when reading the top reviews for Roku devices is that they mostly date back to 2017-2018 and sometimes even before. Please take into account that THIS Roku is the 2019 release date and THAT is the device you will receive and the device that I purchased & reviewed :). I'm sure what other's wrote is valid for their particular Roku based on the release date but rest assured that a review from 2017 or 2018 can NOT cover a product released in 2019! Hope this proves helpful for anyone considering any streaming device (don't judge the newest model on old model reviews)!A little back story, I do own both Rokus (5 now <U+0001F602>- mostly different generations but my two most recent ones are this one and the Ultra) and Amazon Fire Sticks (2 - various generations) and although I enjoy them all for the fact that we were able to cut our cable about 6 years ago thanks to them, I would say I am thoroughly enjoying this one and the Ultra the most. The technology is the most recent release dates and they stream absolutely flawlessly!I chose to purchase this particular Roku for my father because his bedroom is located on the top floor of our home while our modem is connected in our basement which is a concrete box of internet deadzone (the modem must be connected down there or the internet won't reach the entire house unfortunately, but we are in the process of getting booster Pods from Xfinity). We have the now 300 mb Xfinity internet (aka nerdy gaming speeds - was previously 250 mb) with our router/modem located in our basement for optimum connectivity and a WiFi range extender but our house still has connectivity issues with most devices. This Roku is not only 4K but it's supposed to be exceptionally good for connectivity which played a huge role in choosing this particular one.As soon as I plugged this Roku in, it was love at first home screen just as I had experienced with the Ultra that I had purchased several weeks prior. It recognized all my accounts, downloaded everything quickly, was extremely user friendly and the streaming quality is AMAZING. My father had become all too familiar with the loading screens on various streaming devices and we are ecstatic to be able to say goodbye to them for good thanks to the long-range wireless receiver in this bad boy. The picture quality is always exceptional whether streaming HD, HDR or 4K. This particular Roku stick is also so user friendly that my 70 year father (who generally avoids computers and technology like the plague) can even use it! I also believe this to be the best Roku for it's price point. The Ultra is amazing, but is not necessary in my opinion for most users although it too is highly impressive. We are very pleased with this Roku device and would definitely recommend it.***I took side by side photos of his new Roku (this one - the Roku Streaming Stick+) and his older model, the Roku 3. You can see based off the photos the difference in the remotes, particularly that the newer remote is much skinnier and more comfortable in your hand. The volume controls are the same with the exception of the mute button on the new remote. The Roku 3 remote is also shiny and has different channel buttons compared to the Roku Stick+ remote that is a matte black and features newer streaming channels. The new remote also has the on/off button that most Roku's feature and allows you to easily connect to your tv (it literally auto connects for you) and gives you the power to use your Roku remote on your TV as well. Last note, the picture quality is beautiful even on my Dad's older LG flat screen, but my phone only takes sub par pictures of it so don't mind that <U+0001F602>.

author: Erin Michelle

review_title: Wow Roku! you make other companies look so .... BAD!!!! Thank you!!!!
review_text: Original title was: Perfect streaming stick with poor supporting (but mandatory) accessories… however, see updates belowI have bought three units. Two were installed successfully and are working great (with small adjustments described below)!The third one needed to be sent back to Amazon for replacement due to the poor quality and design of its unique power / antenna cable (you can’t find this cable anywhere and it cannot be bought separately). It easily snapped when installed on one of my wall-mounted televisions.In addition, I have a 65-Inch 4K Ultra HD television (Sony XBR-65X900A, a model from 2013) and my single 4K UHD HDCP 2.2 port is placed on the television’s back in an area that cannot fit this stick (due to its size and shape). I needed to add a small flexible extending cord to connect it. Finally, I also got an error message (from Roku) on that same television saying it is not getting enough power from the television’s USB port ... so I had to use the power adaptor that comes with this product. However, the power extender is also a very short cable ...Bottom line, once you get it installed and running (after one week of viewing) the product is great. The sound and picture quality are amazing. I loved the Roku user interface and speedy response. Its only Achilles’ heel is related to its poor proprietary power / antenna cable.UPDATE (November 10, 2017): Amazon quickly replaced the damaged cable and I was contacted by Roku. Roku team provided me with all the help I have needed (well, it should be on its way to me, so I will keep you updated once I'll get it). Thanks a lot Amazon and Roku!UPDATE (November 19, 2017): Today I have opened the door to my beloved FedEx delivery guy and look what I have got from Roku! The three (3) HDMI extenders (as promised) and an additional (and totally new) Roku Streaming Stick+ - all for FREE. Just as a reward for writing this review and adding my comments to it. To remind you, my original review had only four (4) stars (due to the issue with the product's accessory, as described above) – however, now I have updated it to five (5) stars. Because in my book - caring for customers and addressing their needs (and beyond) and making customers feel cared and important – it what makes a company (and its products) prefect. We all know, there are no real perfect products out there. For every product out there, we can always apply our hopes and wishful thinking ("I wish they have added that feature to it", “I wish the screen was bigger”, "I wish they have used that my preferred CPU " and so forth). But a company with a great product and a perfect customer care, how many can you find out there?So, once again - Thank You Roku so much! I really like your product and now admires your service!

review_title: Buyer Beware - Please Read This Before You Buy
review_text: BUYER BEWARE - I've purchased Roku players in August 2012, May 2015, and this new Stream Stick+ in 2018. When I had a problem "activating" my new Streaming Stick+, I was given a number to "Contact Support Toll Free to Activate Instantly". I called the number and was told that since I had already registered 2 other Roku devices, in order to Activate this 3rd device, I would need to pay $70.00 to have a PREMIUM account. I told them that I didn't need nor want a PREMIUM account. I asked the customer service rep, to deactivate the first Roku I purchased in 2012 and then I would only have 2 registered devices on my account. I was told that - (1) Even if I deactivated a previous Roku player or (2 )if I opened a new account, I would still have to pay the $70.00 in order to register my Streaming Stick+ .So that is how Roku rewards it's returning long-time customer, by charging them a fee of $70.00 to activate more than 2 of their Roku devices! So, in addition to paying for the device itself, you now have to pay an extra $70.00 to use it!!!I am hoping this review will alert other potential buyers to Roku's new policy of rewarding their repeat customers.Patti

review_title: Switched to Linux mini PC for all in one Fully Functional PC/Video Streamer for TV
review_text: EDIT:I switched to a mini PC with Linux on my TV because i was tired of the limitations of Roku and the other popular video streaming devices as they all either have no web browser or a poorly functioning web browser.I use the Linux mini PC with a wireless keyboard with touchpad so I can do anything on my TV.All i had to do was adjust the Display settings in Linux to enlarge the text for TV.Rather than use "apps",you just bookmark your favorite websites for video streaming on your web browser.I use the Brave browser which blocks ads.I had been a Roku user for years,including several different models..Here are some points to consider when deciding on which model of Roku to buy:1)If you need to connect by WiFi in a room far away from your WiFi router,I would recommend the Roku Streaming Stick PLUS or Roku Ultra.2)If you have a 4K TV,I would recommend the Roku Ultra or Roku Streaming Stick PLUS.The Premiere 2018 model also plays 4K.3)To search for content using your voice,go with either the Streaming Stick,Streaming Stick PLUS or Ultra.All 3 of these models also have a remote that can control the power and volume on a TV.There is also a Roku app for Android & iPhone/iPad that lets you use your smartphone/tablet to control any Roku device and use your phone/tablet on-screen keyboard for searches.4)If you want a wired ethernet connection,go with the Roku Ultra.5)If you want to connect to an old TV with RCA/Composite audio/video jacks,you will need the Express PLUS6)The Express & Premiere 2018 models have a remote where it has to be pointed at the device,unlike the other Roku models.My gripe about Roku (and other streaming devices) is the lack of a fully functional web browser .I have been surfing the web on the big screen for years and find it ridiculous when an internet connected TV device does not allow you to surf the internet and forces one to switch to yet another internet connected device to do so.I am aware of the screen mirroring function from smartphone/PC/tablet but find that a poor excuse to not include a web browser.Many people who type a lot of messages and/or emails like myself prefer typing on a wireless keyboard rather than a phone/tablet/remote control.

review_text: Spectrum's move to all-digital was my breaking point with my ever-increasing cable bill. I have six televisions, only two of which were using boxes, and this change would mean that I would have to rent an additional four. I have two Apple TV boxes and one Amazon Firestick, and can say that this is much speedier and more reliable than either of them. I've been trying it out for about a week now, and am confident in dropping Spectrum at the end of this billing cycle.By the way - I see that some reviewers have complaints about customer service trying to charge them for setting up the Roku, or for adding or dropping channels, or for troubleshooting. This is a scam perpetrated by someone with nothing at all to do with Roku. An outside entity was able to create a fake Roku site that topped the list when googling "Roku." The phone number you would call if you pulled it from this website was fake and, again, had nothing to do with Roku. Roku was the main victim in this scheme, it's cost them negative feedback all over the internet. Just DON'T google Roku and call any number you find at the site until this is straightened out. Look for a number on the documentation sent with your device. If anyone at the other end of the call tries to charge you for any of these things, you haven't reached the legitimate Roku support guys.

review_text: EARLIER REVIEW: Works just fine* and because our TV is not mounted, the length of the stick is not a problem at all. My husband enjoys the voice command feature and used it occasionally. At some point he was watching the TV and I don't know what he clicked on but the TV started talking--NONSTOP--reading everything on the screen. I was perplexed but, if this happens to you, go into "Accessibility" to turn it off. Apparently it's a feature for the sight-impaired.*LATER REVIEW (EDIT): THIS REMOTE IS A POS, It worked for about five months and then stopped working at all. If I hadn't read some other reviews where people had the same problem and discovered they had to change batteries way too frequently--one person had to remove the batteries every night and then put them back in the next night--I wouldn't have known that changing the batteries might work. We put in new batteries and it worked fine . . . for a few days. Then it stopped again.THE COMPANY'S RETURN POLICY IS A JOKE.I wanted to return it but the company has made it sufficiently difficult and iffy to make most people give up on that idea, given the hoops you have to jump through, the resulting length of time it would take to have your TV viewing restored, and the fact that one of the major faults in this remote seems to be that it eats thought batteries. Also, if the remote's problem was its propensity to eat up the charge in your batteries, the company would likely try new batteries and then send it back saying, "You needed to change the batteries." So basically we have to eat the price of this thing and take a chance on some other model. Or maybe we'll just get some other system than Roku.RETURN AND WARRANTY SERVICE PROCESS [Sorry about spacing; it was in pdf format]Please access and review Roku Support online help resources at support.roku.com before seeking warranty service. Returns orwarranty service requests for your new Player must be within the 30-day return period, or within the original product warrantyperiod.You must first obtain a Return Merchandise Authorization (RMA) number from Roku Customer Support. RMA numbers expire thirty days from issuance. Roku may attempt to troubleshoot a warranty-related problem prior to issuing a RMA number.Please be prepared to provide additional information upon request.Once a RMA number is obtained, you must ship your Player, freight prepaid, together with proof of purchase and all accessories, in either the original packaging or packaging affording an equal degree of protection, to the Roku authorized distribution facility identified by Roku Customer Support.Failure to return any of the accessories could result in a delay and/or result in an invoice to you or credit to Roku for the missing accessories. Important:When submitting a RMA, please provide the following information with your request: (a) modelnumber, (b) serial number,(c) problem description, (d) software version (located in the Settings menu), (e) date of purchase, (f) place of purchase (reseller or online place of purchase), and (g) return shipping address (P.O. boxes are not accepted).Additional Roku troubleshooting and online help resources can be found at support.roku.com

review_title: Possible Problem: Read this review if you care about data usage...
review_text: Read this review if you care about if your ISP limits data use.A little background I am a long time cord cutter, used different devices over the years. Decided to switch due to new service only works on Roku. We use Comcast and have 1TB monthly data limit before fees hit. I also monitor using my routers traffic analyzer to see what is sucking up all my data. After using the Roku Streaming Stick+ for a few days noticed a spike in data use at AM hours and isolated the usage to my new Roku. This version of Roku has a power button to control your TV's power (very handy) Also the Roku can be powered via TV USB or external power supply if your TV's USB ports are too weak. My Roku is plugged into a power supply.**Heres the rub** So by force of habit when I finish watching TV I have been hitting the power button, TV goes off as expected, but the Roku continues to stream the streaming service I was accessing. (disclaimer only tested Prime and PSVUE so far) My router confirmed the damn thing streamed all night long (all night....all night long, dancin in the streets) with the TV off. Also confirmed by just turning the TV off and back on, what ever is being watched is still rolling.**the solution** To date I can't find a setting to time-out based on the Roku nor a method to automatically switch to standby when the TV shuts off without replacing a power strip. So my solution to date is MAKE SURE TO HIT THE HOME BUTTON BEFORE POWERING DOWN THE TV.Other than wasting my internet data it seems like a solid device will post an update if another solution presents itself.

Someone with the thickest accent answered and, OF COURSE, wanted more money to set it all up for a ONE TIME FEE. review_title: Roku supports Charter Spectrum, so I returned my box!
review_text: I bought this to replace a cable box which wasn't being used, so I could return the box. I have Charter Spectrum which is supported by Roku. I received my Roku + yesterday and hooked it up to my living room TV to test it out.Setting It up was easy. I have it plugged into my HDMI on the TV and you have a choice of powering it through a USB port on your TV, or using the included wall plug which you plug the USB end into then plug it into an outlet, which I did.Roku takes you step by step setting it up and you do have to put in a credit card, I used PayPal. That's only if you want to watch something that's not free.I loaded the spectrum app, logged into spectrum with my username and password and have all my channels. Live and on demand. I also love the fact that when I use the Spectrum guide with the app, it only shows the channels I'm signed up for, unlike the guide on my DVR box which makes you scroll through all the channels.The remote control has a voice button that you hold down and say what you are looking for, and it takes you to the Roku app with all the results. To test it out I searched Clint Eastwood and so many movies showed up, but most of them needed to be paid for.I was also very impressed with all the movies and shows that Roku offers. Not all are free, but I set up a pin to prevent any unauthorized charges.I can't comment on the range of the wifi yet, but will update once I do.When I read the directions, there was something about using it with a 4k and there's a free adapter they will send, incase something doesn't fit. I went right onto Roku site and ordered it just to have in case I ever need it.I love this so much, I'm seriously considering getting rid of my DVR service and box on my living room TV to save more money.

author: Reezie

review_text: The Roku Streaming Stick + worked OK, but soon after installing it, other WiFi devices began to get kicked off the network. I noticed in the android WiFI analyzer app that someone had brought up a WiFi access point on the same channel as mine. :( It was also transmitting at a higher power than mine. I soon realized that it was the Roku stick's WiFi Direct connection to its remote. I tried changing my WAP to a different channel, but the Roku followed it there. I tried changing from 2.4 to 5Ghz, but it also followed my access point to the new frequency/channel. I reached out to Roku tech support, and they suggested that I change channels on my WAP...which I'd already done. I informed them that I'd already been down that rabbit hole and they said to try a free HDMI extender? The stick was on a 3 foot extender already. Roku used to have an option in the firmware to try to correct this issue, but they've removed it. I would have given 2 or 3 stars if they'd been more helpful. But as it is, I must highly discourage anyone from purchasing this product until they fix the WiFi design/firmware. I hope they do fix it. If not, I'd probably go for an older Roku model with an infrared remote.

review_title: WORST REMOTE EVER!! DO NOT BUY!! AVOID AVOID AVOID!!
review_text: Immediately right out of the box I had nothing but problems with the Roku remote: the "UP" arrow on the scrolling cross only worked about half the time (it would make the "ding" sound when pushed but wouldn't move anything on the screen) which for a streaming device is completely unacceptable. Think about how much time a person spends scrolling through menus! So thinking this was simply a defective remote, I bought another brand new Roku Streaming Stick+ and took the remote out of the box and synced it with my system and guess what? This time the "Left" button on the scrolling cross only worked about half the time (again it would make a sound but wouldn't actually do anything on the screen) AND the power button did a "double tap" about 75% of the time: If the TV was on and I pushed the power button I would hear two "clicks" and the TV would turn off and then turn back on again! Same thing if the TV was off and I hit the power button- I would hear two clicks and the TV would turn on and then turn back off. Again- completely unacceptable.And the worst part about this is that Roku has known that their remotes are cheap and inferior quality and have done NOTHING to fix them! In reading older reviews on Amazon (something I should have done before purchasing) tons of other customers have complained about the low quality of Roku remotes for the last 18 months, and while Roku has commented on a few of these reviews offering only lame platitudes, they have done NOTHING to actually fix the problem.ATTENTION ROKU: It is clear that you're losing thousands of customers due to the shoddy quality of your remote controls...maybe that's something you should address??In the meantime I returned both my Roku Streaming Stick+ and bought the Amazon Fire TV Stick 4K and found it is FAR SUPERIOR!!!!! review_title: Works Great, but becareful of Overheating and Bandwidth use
review_text: Been using this for about a week now and overall I am really happy with it, but becareful of overheating and bandwidth use if your ISP is capped (mine is capped to 1.2TB per month which I need for other stuff too besides roku)Because of the overheating I had to add a fan near it and it dropped the temp from 82c to 66c in the secret screen (see pictures)to access the secret screen to see the temp hit this remote key combo:Home, Home, Home, Home, Home, Fast Forward, Pause, Rewind, Pause, Fast ForwardFor the bandwidth control you will want to go into your Router Settings (see last picture) and enable Traffic Management (QoS) and adjust the downstream to just enough for the Resolution you want to stream at, for me I use 1080p, and 3mbps down is just enough for 1080p streaming and I been able to stay around 15 to 20GB a day (0.5 to 0.8GB per hour) (450 to 600GB per month)Another thing you can do to save bandwidth is go into Roku Settings > Privacy > Advertising and check the box on "Limit Ad Tracking" and then restart the roku stick to apply the settingHave fun, hope this review was helpful

author: Gerald

review_text: Don't normally write reviews unless they are extraordinarily good or extraordinarily bad. For what it worth, here is a Two-in-One review to illustrate the opposite ends of the spectrum.The Extraordinarily Bad: Roku Customer Service & Technical SupportIn an effort to cut the cord and start streaming, did my research to determine the best content (Amazon Prime Video, Netflix, DirecTV, Youtube TV, etc.) and hardware (Amazon Fire sticks, Apple TV, Google Chromecast, Roku's, etc.) required for the entire family to enjoy. From the hardware perspective, settled on Roku sticks because Youtube TV did not (at the time) support Fire sticks for obvious reasons. Started as a trial with a Roku stick against the some streaming providers listed above, and it worked quite well. So ended up buying a total of 5 Roku streaming sticks (3 to keep and 2 to share) on various occasions in 2018 on Amazon. One of them stopped working after a few months but still was under 1 year warranty. Spent a few days troubleshooting by mixing and matching the configurations of the 3 sticks against 4 different TV sets under 2 different WIFI networks. The results consistently showed that the stick in question (the stick itself and not the remote nor the TVs nor the WIFI networks) worked intermittently for a few minutes then the TV screens went blank.Contacted Roku as follow:1. Logged a ticket on Roku website indicating the problem as such. No response for several days until after calling them in next step.2. Called technical support explaining the problem and the troubleshooting process above. They said they'll send an HDMI extender.3. Received the extender 2 weeks later, but it did not work at all - no audio, no video, just blank screen. The problem was actually worst since using the stick without the extender would at least work for a few minutes then stopped.4. Called them the following day. They admitted that they had sent a bad part and will make sure to send a "working" HDMI extender. It never arrived. Probably never send it.5. After 2 weeks of waiting, called them again and explained the troubleshooting process all over again (for the 4th time). They said they will send a remote. With patience running thin, asked the tech support rep why would she send a remote when the stick is the problem. After a brief silence, she asked to wait for a few minutes then came back and said an email with instructions on how to return the stick for a replacement will be sent.6. Three days later, still no email. And no, it's not in spam folder. Simply put - they lied the second time. Frustrated but decided to give them a final chance to rectify the problem and called one last time. After 25 minutes, a rep finally answered then the line got cut off immediately. Coincidence?Bottom line: The problem had been reported for over a month and still no resolutions. The average wait time for each call is 30+ minutes due to the so called "heavy call volume". They sent bad part and lied their way out of honoring their warranty.The Extraordinarily Good: Amazon Customer ServiceFrustrated and planned to just throw away the stick, but also decided to give Amazon a call to inform the type of service Roku had provided with the hope that if this is the norm, Amazon will think twice before selling Roku products on its site. The Amazon CS rep apologized, offered a refund, and will work with Roku on the issue. Didn't expect that! After all, this is a Roku's problem not Amazon's. The call took less than 5 minutes. Problem solved. Thank you Amazon. This is another reason for being a Prime member.In the streaming war against giants like Amazon, Google, Apple, Disney, etc. and with the type of service Roku had provided, good luck Roku. For your survival in this crowded space, you (Roku) should take a page out of Amazon's playbook and learn from it. Otherwise, you will be crushed like a cockroach that you are.Update:Finally received the Warranty Swap email from Roku four days after the call in step 5 above (a few hours after posting this review). Decided to ignore it as so much time had already been wasted. It's unfortunate that the device worked quite well (when and if it worked), but the customer service is unbearable.

review_title: They try to trick you into giving your credit card, but it isn't necessary.
review_text: I've never had a Roku before. This is well priced for what you get and the streaming is good quality. There are a few big caveats, though.The first is that Roku try to trick you into putting in a credit card. As you first sign up, the interface gives you no option to avoid this (!), but it actually isn't necessary to function. You have to stop your registration at the point they ask and restart the roku. Then, just log into the website. Works fine without the CC. I guess marketing thought it was a good idea to force customers to give payment info. It is kind of scummy.The second is that search is lousy. Search within individual channels is awkward, and the main Roku search interface doesn't differentiate between movies on channels you already have, and movies on new channels they want you to subscribe to. By mixing them all, they try to force you to sign up for more channels, I suppose, but it is at the cost of a easy to use search function.The third is that there is no general history or resume. If you stop in the middle of a movie there is no indication when you turn the machine back on of what you were watching or where you stopped. You have to remember to go back into whatever channel you were in, and look for the specific movie again. Remembering current status is basic functionality, and the whole thing is made worse if you have more channels as Roku encourages. Surely Roku could figure out how to resume properly. I purchased this for my elderly parents, all this lack of basic function makes their lives considerably more complicated. It is a shame, since those things would be so easy to do right and the streaming itself is fabulous.

review_title: A GREAT Roku, Follow directions and you won’t get scammed...
review_text: Let me preface this with I have owned every single Roku since the initial model (over a decade ago now). Roku as a platform has grown exponentially since then, and I am proud to use them on all of my TVs. This Roku stick is almost indistinguishable from its full size counter part in terms of speed and quality. I went with the stick form because it was for a projector and I did not want to run another HDMI cable through the ceiling.For those who are posting about a scam or being held “hostage” by support, make sure you actually go to Roku’s website, and check the SSL certificate. (This is why we don’t google URLs when they’re presented to you on the screen...). Roku does not force any fee to activate and they don’t cap the number of devices (they don’t even require a payment method on file to use, unlike another streaming stick I know). If you were told otherwise, you were made a fool of by a scammer who took advantage of you not checking the URL.The new remote with this stick is so light and thin, a major improvement over the older generations! My only complaint is that the library of remote commands (TV power, volume and mute) is restricted to TVs- not AVRs and Projectors. You can usually google it and find a brand that uses the same code to map it to get it to work- just not as simple.While I’m a firm believer in always wiring streaming devices to your network (I.e. Ethernet port), this stick does a great job streaming 4K over WiFi regardless of the fact that it’s in a terrible spot for WiFi coverage (behind a projector with a lot of interference and hanging off the ceiling).

review_title: BEWARE: Does not work on older TV's !!!! Get Roku Express instead.
review_text: It pains me to give a bad review to Roku because I have another Roku TV and I love it! This is not a ding on the product itself, but more on the product page. The product page neglects to explain the importance of HDCP 2.2 standard. It is some sort of copyright protection technology so that you can't make recordings of 4k HDR streams. Older TV's that are only 1080p compliant (basically anything older that 2013-ish) won't have the proper copyright ability and the Roku device won't work with it AT ALL. I wish that it was more explicitly explained in the product page that if you want Roku on an older 1080p TV, you have to buy the ROKU EXPRESS device, instead. I had a very bad experience trying to get this to work on my non-smart TV. After several hours searching the internet, i finally learned of the problem. I knew that my TV was not 4K, but I just thought that the steaming stick would just dumb down the quality for my TV. I didn't think it would completely not work.

review_text: Luckily the scam I'm talking about is in no way Roku's fault. When setting up my Roku I attempted to pull the Roku site on my phone and punch in the code. Apparently there's either a REALLY good spoof website, or the actual one is somewhat infiltrated, because I got a message that my Roku was "temporarily locked" and that I needed to call them. I've set up a few of these devices before, so I was already on alert. I called the number and was set up with "Roku customer service" who offered to fix the device and get me started, but said they'd need to charge me a one-time fee to access over 50 Roku channels. If you've used Roku before you know this is not the case. We went back and forth a bit. The Roku setup screen even states that there is no fee to set up. I asked the "technician" about this, and they gave some excuse about how charging me money to activate me was not an "activation" fee. I was getting more suspicious, and requested a supervisor, which I'm not sure wasn't the same person. The "supervisor" offered me a "supervisor's discount" of $10. It's interesting to note that the base activation fee kept changing from $49 to $69. I eventually got very suspicious, told them I was investigating further, and hung up on them. I then went my desktop computer upstairs (which I was too lazy to do before) and activated the Roku that way, and was streaming in a matter of minutes.I Googled it later, and apparently it's a fairly common scam. Don't believe me? Look for yourself.Roku makes a wonderful product. My original ones are still running okay, but I've been upgrading a bit this year. I've been consistently happy with their performance. I highly recommend them. Just be careful when you go to register.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2020
author: Termitesforhire

review_title: Cheap 4K streaming and a very good remote that turns your TV on/off and adjusts TV volume.
review_text: I owned a previous-generation Roku and needed to add a couple more as we moved from cable to streaming via SlingTV. I was skeptical of the stick, thinking it would be slow and limited. But I've had these now for almost a year and they are great. This is the 2017 version of the Roku Streaming Stick (the + indicates it supports 4K video.) It's a good device, and this and its non + twin both feature a wonderful remote control that can turn your TV off or on -- and adjust the volume. This means that most of the time you'll only need one remote control -- a great feature. You also get voice commands.If you haven't used streaming video before, you may be confused by the options such as Roku, Amazon's Fire, Google's Chromecast and Android TV, and Apple TV. You choose a device and then there are available apps for various pay- and free streaming services. Services such as SlingTV, youtube TV, Direct TV Now, Hulu Live, and Playstation Vue all provide selections of cable and broadcast channels live -- basically cable without the cable. There are literally hundreds of other free services on Roku, with wide ranges of content AND quality.Having used this product for the better part of a year, I can easily recommend it, unless you need a hard-wired solution such as the Roku Ultra.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2018
author: S. McCallister

review_title: Great for watching Netflix and Youtube, much better than Apple TV
review_text: I mainly got this for watching Netflix since my TV can no longer connect to the internet on its own. I also started pairing it with my phone to watch YouTube videos - and I LOVE the fact that unlike AirPlay (with Apple TV), I don't have to stay on YouTube on my phone to continue watching YouTube on the TV - I can even call or use other apps, and even quit the YouTube app on my phone and videos will still play!Not to mention, the remote has more than 5 buttons (unlike the Apple TV remote), including a handy volume button and a Netflix button, which automatically takes me to Netflix, even if the TV isn't on! Love these little features.However, after a few days, I was no longer able to connect/share my iPhone or MacBook screen to the TV/Roku Stick. The Roku Streaming option stopped appearing under "Connect to" menu. I'm only able to connect my phone to the TV when playing YouTube, since YouTube always has a cast option at the top and still lists Roku Streaming as available to connect.If you experience this issue as well, I recommend downloading the WebCaster app - you can paste the link of websites (other than YouTube) into the app and the option to stream it on your Roku TV will appear.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2021
author: Michele

review_text: Interested in "cutting the cord", I researched the best streaming devices, and found that the Roku Streaming Stick+ was consistently in the top 5 and was the best value for the money for our particular family. I was able to choose same-day delivery, and received them in the late afternoon. They were contained in a larger box, so no one could see what was in the package, and the delivery person thoughtfully put them behind a half-wall in our entry court, rather than right in front of the door where they could be seen from the street, which I appreciated!When removed from the box, the items were just as described, in unopened, original packaging. The quick start guide takes you step-by-step through attaching the Roku to your TV and syncing it to the remote, and from that point on, you simply follow the on-screen directions as it walks you through setting up your Roku account (free - but keep in mind that you will need a laptop, desk computer, or phone present in order to access the Roku website to do this), linking your device to it, and starting to use it. It was easy to add the streaming services we already had, such as Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime, and interesting to browse the many free options available and add the ones we wanted - the Western TV & Movie Classics" channel is a big hit with my husband and his dad. Once set up, there are links on the home page to a "Getting Started" with Roku page, and a "Tips and Tricks" to Using Roku page for more information regarding your Roku, in addition to tiles for whatever channels you chose during your set-up.We have been using these (we installed two in our home, and one in my 90-year-old father-in-law's home) for a month now, and have had no issues whatsoever. We have not had any problems with lag, and pictures are clear and bright (any fuzziness in the photos I've provided are the fault of the camera operator!). The user interface is pretty standard for this type of thing - the biggest learning curve we faced was figuring out exactly which apps the shows we normally watched were on. However, between being able to customize which streaming apps appear on your home page, and the two ways to search - you can either type in the name in the search bar, or you can hold down a microphone-iconed button on the remote and, for example, say "Search Criminal Minds", it is fairly easy to get to where you want to be without having to flounder around in the interface. Even dad-in-law, who is somewhat electronically challenged, got the hang of it fairly quickly, and is very comfortable with using the interface at this point. We are all very happy with the device and service. Highly recommended!NOTE: Regarding the stick being at the side of the TV in our photo, in case anyone is concerned about the aesthetics of having this sticking out of your TV - there were other HDMI ports we could have used at the back of the TV, where the stick would have been hidden and only the Roku power cord coming down next to the TV power cord would have been visible. However, these were difficult for me to reach, and since my husband is not very technologically savvy, I am the one who usually deals with the electronics and troubleshoots when there are problems, so I was more concerned with the device being easily accessible that I was about how it looked. Rest assured, if you want a neater look, it is certainly available if you choose to use an HDMI port at the back of your TV. :- )
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2019
author: Catherine A. Adams

review_title: So glad that we upgrade to a newer version of a Roku Stick
review_text: My family has owned 2 other Roku Sticks and have gotten a huge amount of use out of each one. One of the sticks we use everyday, many hours a day, with our streaming service, making the roku stick is our primary way of watching TV. By and large, the sticks have worked really well for many years.But recently, as the quality/quantity of TV streaming increased, we found that having a Roku stick that was quite a few years old, wasn't performing as well as would like. It still worked, but we found it dragged when trying to search or trying to scroll through the, seemingly, hundreds of channels/options that are available.So, it was time for an upgrade. We choose the Streaming Stick Plus and, after using for a few months now, we wish we had upgraded far sooner.The new stick is easily able to handle the demands that streaming puts on it . Each channel we choose comes up much faster than with the old sticks. I think, though i don't know i can prove it, that the new stick is able to receive/utilize a stronger wifi signal, especially as compared to the older model.The on-screens controls that come with the newer, upgraded version of the roku are much easier to use. the new remote, with built-in controls to turn the tv on/off, to control the volume of the tv and to mute the volume of the tv means that having a seperate, tv only, remote isn't needed.And, we've have not only been having fun using the voice controls on the remote, we've found the voice controls to be an extremely helpful shortcut for many different sites.I haven't yet tried hooking the roku up to Alexa, as that isn't a major plus for me, but I might try doing that in the future.so now i'm thinking that it might be a good time to go ahead and upgrade that one remaining, older roku that we have. yep, that sounds like a good idea to me.

author: Shakey Town

review_text: I've being using the Amazon Firestick for a year without any complaints. When needed to buy a second streaming unit, Amazon wouldn't send theirs to a forwarding address. This forced me to buy a different brand: Roku.At the beginning I wasn't happy (resistance to change) but as soon as I started using it all I could say is: WOW!! THIS IS GOOD!Roku is very fast and responsive. The interface can be customized and I believe it is better. I get exactly the same functionality as before, but with a faster response time. I love the fact the the Roku controller can turn on/off the TV and control the volume; makes streaming a bit easier. When the cell is used as a controller, the sound can be heard through earbuds without any noticeable lag.I'm very happy with this streaming stick. Roku is highly recommended, and will never go back.

author: Maximo Ortiz

review_text: I happen to get my first ROKU about a year back at Home Depot. It sat on the shelf for 6 months until I was at a location with high speed internet before I attempted to use it but since then, I have grown to use it with more and more appreciation each time.The first thing I did was to sign up for CBS All Access ($10US/mo) and I had Amazon Prime. The picture quality is definitely HD and as good or better than satellite HD with the upside that so many "channels" are available of my own choosing. There is a lot of free material available outside any subscriptions and beside the subscriptions, there is one-time buy offered on those things you really want. There is no charge for ROKU services and ROKU bills any charges through the provider you choose (simple set-up for each). After that, it's just like punching into a channel. On top of that, the ROKU Streaming Stick + offers voice recognition so you can search for things using voice prompts and ROKU is very good at it (actually excellent). If an old movie (or other video content) is available, ROKU can find it using a voice prompt. YouTube works the same way and voice prompting saves a lot of typed in requests for searching. I had very rare glitches on a 1.5MB/s internet connection, and none on my home 3MB/s service (though not using any other device at the time) - just rock-solid video and audio.In summary, I would recommend this item to anyone interested in streaming programming and feel it is a great deal for the low cost it is offered at.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
author: Robert D.

review_text: I've had several Roku's and the stick is the best so far. It typically streams very well, but streaming isn't flawless. Having said that, I cannot confirm that it is a Roku issue. We are on GigaBit service, but it is not perfect. Hulu isn't perfect and we're pretty sure the service has gone down for a few minutes, but it's rare. Netflix occasionally doesn't stream, but by the time we check using another device the Roku is streaming again, so it tough to tell. There are a lot of variables. The Roku stick seems to be more reliable than earlier Roku devices, but still has moments of confusion and it self-reboots, but it seems like this happens less than once a month and it's only down a minute or so. When we had cable, it went out more often and for longer periods. Never had a dish, but friends who do complain about it not working and not available in every room.Yes, if you don't want to move the stick from room to room and reboot it, every TV has to have one, but our cable company made us have a box on every TV and they charged us rent for them every month (3 months was about the cost of a Roku stick). Some TVs now have apps built in, but the Roku allows us to add (and remove) channels and services our TV didn't come with and keeps them all in one easy place.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2020
author: JAS

review_text: I have owned this unbelievable piece of technology for about 10 days so please give my review the weight you deem appropriate. So far, I only have two complaints. The mute button on the remote is poorly located and too easily accidentally pressed and occasionally the remote is a little sluggish in responding. Easily connected, setup and activated, the device provides a mind-numbing number and variety of apps and channels with excellent picture and audio. For those who choose to connect directly to av receivers I recommend you set the device audio to Dolby Digital plus. You will then enjoy multi-channel sound where available. You may also need an hdmi extension cable. Although Roku will send one free of charge upon request it’s only about 4 inches long and practically useless. Amazon sells several and I purchased a 6ft one from UGreen that works perfectly. I power my stick from a USB jack on the TV. Roku recommends using the supplied adapter and connecting to an electric socket so it remains powered on at all times eliminating start up delay. However, it only takes a few seconds to power on from the USB connection and this method also eliminates any heat build-up (however marginal) when the TV is off. Some may argue that having the unit fire up every time the TV is turned on is likely to reduce longevity. Of course this is the same argument advanced for computers and some other electronic devices. I’ll leave that choice to you after noting that heat is a nemesis of electronic devices of virtually all kinds. Use the power option that works for you. Once set up you can literally spend hours just surfing through the staggering number of apps and channels. Absolutely amazing device. I’ll follow up if my opinion changes.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2020
author: Jim Bob Jones

review_text: I have had a bad history with 4K Roku devices. With my new 4K system I tried to use first the Premiere+, then the Ultra, and finally the Streaming Stick+, all played through the A/V receiver in my living room's 7.2 system. All three devices failed with HDCP 2.2 errors. Despite the fact that all components in my new system were 2.2 compatible, the Rokus would stop the entire system because its software apparently imagined that I had a recording device attached to my receiver. A Stick+ plugged directly into the 4K TV in my bedroom worked fine.I last sent Roku an email about the problem in April 2018. I had long since returned all the devices to Amazon for credit. Then in February 2019, ten months later, I received an email from Roku stating that the software problem had been corrected and that I should be able to use 4K devices. I decided to give it one last chance and bought a Stick+ for the living room. I've had it for about a week and it seems to be working fine.I gave it 4 stars rather than 5 because (a) it took Roku TEN MONTHS to fix this problem and I don't imagine that I'm the only person who experienced it and (b) they put these devices on the market before they were functioning properly.Not everyone plugs their devices directly into their TV, and Roku should have an effective way to correct problems in a timely fashion. None of the other 2.2 compatible devices I have has ever had any 2.2 problems.

author: Detroit Mike

review_title: Roku stick helps you cut your satellite/cable tv bill!
review_text: Never used a Roku stick before but I wanted to cut cable. It was insanely easy to install and setup. A keyboard definitely would make the sign in process easier but I was able to proceed anyways.I didn’t like that you have to think about what you want to watch. With cable you flip it on and find something interesting. I have gotten used to it though and have found some really great shows on Hulu. Nothing is Live. If I want Live the Hulu Live is an additional 54.99 per month. If I want News I guess Pluto is the way to go. With the Roku stick and streaming you can definitely binge on specific shows. In fact I over binged as I didn’t know how to change channels at first ( top arrow to left pulls up guide )Unfortunately I was unable to cut my cable completely. I added spectrum TV. I love love love it. I had direct TV prior and was paying about $300 per month for internet plus satellite tv. Crazy! With the roku stick on 2 of my TVs ... I have A spectrum DVR and cable on the main tv ( instant tv:)) and the spectrum tv app on the other 2.( a 4th tv has the Xbox one which can download the spectrum app). I still have Hulu for $5 a month . My total now is about $200. The Roku sticks have definitely helped me cut down on my tv entertainment bills. They are really easy to use for someone who isn’t tech savvy. They are portable since you create a Roku account ( free) and plug them into the hdmi spot on The TV. You can either plug them into a wall outlet or the usb tv port for power. They also act as the digital box you need to rent from your cable company if your TV isn’t smart.I feel that the Roku stick has allowed me to get closer to my goal of cutting cable completely. They are definitely user friendly:) Five stars Roku!!

review_text: Having read too many comments that the USB power would not work, I was skeptical. But it works. One less power cable. Actually, why would not? I think all TV sets' USB ports are power USB anyway. Surprisingly, such a tiny device. I tried all other streamers with Android TV. Preferred Roku for 1. powered USB and 2. interface. I think the latter wins over the others for very clean design, not cluttered as others. Like Roku channel with Live news. I thinks it's much cleaner interface and easier to navigate than Peacock.What I don't get it is why this piece of fabric on the remote with the logo. What's the point? I think it even makes the production more expensive. Why not to stamp the Roku logo on the remote itself? There is a lot of room for those four letters. Also, I wish the volume controls were on top of the remote, not on the side. But it's survivable.

author: Yuri Budnyatsky

review_text: I bought this Roku Streaming Stick+ in October 2018 to replace my old FireStick which was really slow and old and frustrating to use because it would suddenly stop in the middle of a show and go back to the home page.The Roku was easy to set up, and worked great for a couple of months. In December we had the first problem: it wouldn't work: just showed a bad picture with zigzagging lines. We reset it and couldn't get the picture to show up at the right size: it was enormous. Called tech support, and the guy helped us fix that problem. Then another problem presented: no audio and Roku remote won't control TV. I don't remember what I did to fix it, but it started working again. Good deal.We were gone for a week during the holidays. Came back and the Roku worked fine up until 2 weeks ago. Same problem as before. My husband was home, and he did what the technician had us do the first time: reset the unit and start over with setup. All good, but now the audio is not coming through again and we can't control the TV with the Roku remote. I couldn't remember what I did to fix it, so I called tech support. The guy had us try several things to get the remote to work and the sound to come through, but nothing worked. He said he could replace the unit, but we would have to return the one we have before they would send out the new one, and that I would get an email explaining how to ship it back and where to ship it. A day or two later, I got an email telling me that my case was "under review." Then I got another couple of emails asking me how they had done! I told them that I was not happy and explained about never getting an email with return merchandise information. That was 2 days ago.They sent another auto-reply. Today, I looked and they had send another "how did we do" email. I clicked on the link to let them know that my issue is still unresolved, and their web page says that they closed my ticket!!!

author: S. Larkin

review_title: Resolution upgrade AND it connects to new TV through AV receiver
review_text: This is my fourth Roku (the oldest one finally died after many (8?) years, and this one is an upgrade from a conventional 1080 Roku Stick). Didn't have any of the problems with registration highlighted by another reviewer. My old Roku Stick connected just fine through the streaming box HDMI input of my Onkyo 4K capable AV receiver to my old Sharp 1080 TV, but when I upgraded to a Samsung 4K TV, the new TV didn't recognize the video signal from the old Roku Stick when it passed through the AV receiver. (Note: the old Stick worked fine connected directly to a HDMI port on the new TV). Anyway, I decided to get a 4K Roku Stick+ to match the resolution of the new TV. As a bonus, the Stick+ works fine passing the video signal through the AV receiver to the new TV. Unfortunately, with this configuration, the Stick+ remote control does NOT control the TV power and volume (no surprise there), but I'm confident it would work if I connected the Stick+ directly to a HDMI port on the new TV. However, in my set-up, the TV is wall-mounted so it's "cleaner" to use the AV receiver as the "command center" for all the HDMI video inputs by placing peripherals (AV receiver, blu-ray, boxes, etc.) on an adjacent shelf/table and use a single cable from the AV receiver to send the selected video signal to the TV.Bottom line, the Roku Stick+ provides an upgrade in video resolution to match my new TV, and also solves the problem of passing the Roku video signal through the AV receiver to the TV. 5 stars.

review_text: We live in Thailand, and stream everything from back home. The furnished apartment did not come with smart TVs, so we replaced the one in the living room. The 50" TV from the living room went to the MBR, and I purchased this little gem so that we could stream all of our existing content, plus what Roku added.Super east to set up, works great, no issues with streaming or connections, and saved us another several hundred bucks purchasing another smart TV. author: Richard S.

review_text: I purchased the Roku Streaming Stick in 2016 and was happy with it. The Streaming Stick+ is an improved version with voice recognition that works well and the added TV controls to the remote is a handy new feature.The Stick+ is connected to a 2014 Sony 1080p TV. Set up was quick and easy. What's particularly nice about the Stick+ is that it stays hidden behind the TV so there's no additional clutter. Using the 5 GHz band, streaming quality is excellent with great picture and no issues with buffering. It's a great streaming device that offers a wide variety of both paid and free content.One nit is that while Roku claims the Stick+ has long-range wireless capability, I've found the wireless range is similar to the 2016 Streaming Stick with no discernible improvement. The Stick+ in my bedroom has no issues with either the 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz bands which is about 30 feet from the router. A Stick+ used in another bedroom about 12 feet farther away from the router has difficulty accessing the 5GHz band and really only works with the 2.4 GHz band.I've read other reviews which state the Stick+ tends to overheat. Even now during the heat of summer and after using the Stick+ for several hours at a time, I haven't that issue in 3 months of use. The only real problem I've had is that the device indicated that there was insufficient power. The Stick+ is powered through the TV's USB port. Simply unplugging the USB connector and plugging it back in solved that problem. It's happened only once and hasn't come up again. Overall, this device is trouble-free.This is my second Roku product and has cemented Roku as my my favorite streaming device. It's tough to go wrong with Roku.

author: ed18

review_title: I was skeptical, but this is great. As good a quality as the larger player
review_text: ROKU makes lots of streaming devices. I have the larger ones for my home system where I want multiple input/output options.I needed one for a simple bedroom TV and decided it was time to try the stick.It plugged directly into the HDMI port. It does need a USB power supply. My TV has a USB port, but only has power when the TV is one. So, if you use the TV port, the ROKU will need to power up each time you turn on the TV. That takes about 30 seconds.It's better to use the included USB power supply, which powers the stick at all times and avoids the ROKU power up issue.Reception and streaming is great. I have had no issues. It connects to the WIFI and has every option I need.My only grief is that ROKU seems to keep adding stations to my viewing options that I have to delete. It is almost like the cell phone with all those apps you don't need, don't want, and didn't ask for.The good news is that they are easy to remove....but they seem to keep on adding more and more apps that have to be deleted.Overall, I'm very happy. Easy integration and good quality.

author: Homer

review_text: As a long time fire tv user, it was time to make a switch after my Fire TV box died after 3 years. I tried the Fire Stick 4k, but after it trying to complete updates for 4 hours, I decided to return it. Boy am I glad I did. The set up on the Roku is way simpler. I like that the home screen just shows apps, rather than the Fire TV interface which bombards you with ads. I like that the home screen can be customized and reorganized while the Fire TV had different screens you had to navigate through to find certain channels. I did have to toy around with it, plugging it into different HDMI ports to get the best configuration, but that is more on my TV than the Roku. My only issue with it is that you have to use the power USB cable that it comes with and it is not too long, but I plan on buying an USB extension cord, as I prefer it to be plugged into an outlet. If you are debating between the Fire TV and this, buy this. I am a devoted Amazon user, but this product is worth every penny!

author: Rickey R.

review_text: I wanted to connect a smaller flat screen TV in my home, but not have to pay an extra $9/month for cable box service. I tried pulling in local stations with an antenna, but I got no signal. I then bought this ROKU stick. Plugged it into my TV USB port, followed the directions, set my TV controls to USB, followed the ROKU onscreen directions, and VOILA! I am pulling in LOTS of TV stations, plus at least 20 cable channels. review_text: When it comes to streaming media devices, IMHO Roku is the brand to beat. I already had an older Roku, which I've used since 2012. When I decided to move it into my bedroom, I realized I wanted something more than the few "smart" apps on my living room TV. A few months later, she upgraded her bedroom TV -- larger and better screen, but again no "smart" apps -- and then she injured her hip and had to spend a couple of weeks off her feet as much as possible. Ity was nearly Christmas anyway, so I bought her another Streaming Stick+, and this time she loved it! (She's hooked on "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel".)Then I decided to give a Streaming Stick+ to my sister for Christmas. Yep, she loves it too! She prefers classic movies and TV series from her childhood, and the various Roku channels have a wealth of such programming. Dhr has hinted that she wouldn't mind having a second Streaming Stick+, for her bedroom TV; so I may be guying my fifth one soon. Or perhaps my fifth and sixth, since the Streaming Stick+ has a few channels available that my original Roku doesn't seem to have.

author: Vanessa D

review_title: Got sick and tired of paying through the nose to be forced to watch endless commercials
review_text: Recently we got just sick and tired of paying $140 a month to be forced to watch endless commercials and ten-year-old reruns. I have been an Amazon Prime member and a real fan of the Fire TV Stick I've been using in addition to my cable service for years now, so when we decided to cut the cable bill and upgrade to a newer version of the Firestick we became interested in the ROKU Streaming Stick as well because we have heard a lot of great things about ROKU too. So I got one of each. I don't regret either. And I DONT miss the cable bill either!The ROKU streams beautifully, rarely ever an issue, EVER, with pausing to buffer; Loss of signal NEVER happens, and the picture is crisp and clear--actually as good as if not better than what I experienced with paid-for cable TV. My only real complaint is the sound: I have to crank-up the volume on my TV to get enough volume to understand what is going on.I enjoy the flexibility that ROKU offers in-that I can sign-on to Prime, HULU, or any channel available, including the ROKU Channel (Which I've come to enjoy immensely). I love that I have control to watch what I want, when I want it, without having to spend 40% of the time I've PAID for being force-fed ad after ad after ad, ad-nauseum. On most free Channel Apps I find they only show two to four commercials per break, and there are fewer breaks making the advertising tolerable. I don't mind watching a few ads to compensate for watching TV for free. I just HATE watching endless commercials on a service that I'm paying for!I also like that you can purchase or rent movies right from your TV and that there are so many new releases available.Sure! The move to ROKU has taken some adjustment, but it's soooooo much better than cable TV! And I'm putting that 140 bucks a month I used to spend on cable TV to much better use.

review_title: Packed with features and well worth it

Some people have complained that the Roku remote is not friendly since it doesn't have a keypad, but the settings button will open a virtual keypad and allow you to enter a TV channel. It takes an extra step, but that is a minor inconvenience and, for me, not worth the loss of a star when you consider all that you get. Setup was a breeze, picture quality is excellent, and operation is responsive and easy. My only regret is that I didn’t buy this sooner.

author: Kindle Customer

review_title: Roku is a royal PITA!!! Unendurable any more! Avoid it. Get an Amazon Firestick instead
review_text: This Roku Streaming Stick + has been a royal PITA since I first got it. First of all was the multiple instances in which I had to log in with a username and password just to get access to the various apps. I could understand being required to do this perhaps once for each app (to register for each service), but not multiple times for the same app. I am in the comfort and security of my own home on a password protected (automatic entry for all my devices ALL DAY EVERY DAY) wifi system. I am not worried about hackers or otherwise unauthorized use of their streaming service. Nor should Roku.Undoubtedly, the Fast Forward and Rewind functions are the most aggravating and infurating things about the service, or lack thereof. Both are either too slow or way too fast. And the 10 second rewind function (why no 10 second FFWD option-ignorant!) no longer works. It will freeze the picture and after a 10 second delay or so, it will pick up right back where you left off, with no rewind. And ostensibly, it should be additive, such that if I press this button 5 times, it will go back 50 seconds. But it doesn't do so. And trying to find your way back to a scene you missed for whatever reason is maddening. It takes the patience of a monk to endure the slowest rewind speed. And there is no rational progression beyond that for the next increments of FFWD or REW speeds. It goes into hyper drive on the second push, what is typically reserved for the 3rd or 4th press of the button. Moreover, I have encountered too many disruptions of service where the picture freezes during buffering. To top it all off, customer service is a nightmarish merry-go-round to get through.Don't waste your money. The Amazon firestick does not put me/you through any of this mess, delivers consistent performance, offers both a 10 second rewind AND forwarding function, does not make you log in multiple times (only had to do so twice; one other for Sling subscription initiation), has only frozen in buffering once or twice for less than 10 seconds each time and has a better interface (which helps you find the shows you'd be interested in quicker). Moreover, Amazon customer service is excellent and readily available for help. I had one instance in which I allowed their technician active X remote control. He quickly, quietly and politely resolved the problem. I WILL NEVER BUY ANOTHER ROKU DEVICE AS LONG AS I LIVE!!! I AM GOING TO STICK THIS POS ON A TV I RARELY USE, OR SELL IT TO SOMEONE ELSE AND LET THEM DEAL WITH IT!

I don't know why people get so worked up about that.Anyway, the remote is good quality and if you set it up it'll be your only remote since it controls the tv power and volume. You might need a second remote to change your HDMI input but I'm not yet 100% sure about that because the Roku is the only thing I personally keep plugged in.I've been through 3 Rokus at this point and this one is by far the best and fastest one. 10/10 would recommend.

review_text: This is our 3rd Roku. I'm back on Amazon to buy a fourth, another one like this. It's so much easier to search with the voice function. On New Year's Eve we returned our cable box and are saving over $125 a month. So far we seems to have a better selection of shows WE want to watch with the Roku Channels and our Fire Stick. We haven't had any problems with the remote recognizing the stick, which is in an HDMI port in the back of the TV. The only time we lost our signal was the power plug falling out of the Roku. Now, with COVID and everyone at home -- apparently permanently -- they don't have enough servers to manage the number of customers online all the time. Also, change batteries when the remotes get wonky. I have a lot of high quality (Panasonic Eneloop) batteries rechargeables and at least I know I'm not adding more poison to local dumps. You can bury the batteries on Amazon and they really ARE the best by far. author: David p.

review_text: I bought this Roku several months ago. For a while it worked. But as of about 4 weeks ago the remote started having a hard time connecting with the Roku itself. It would periodically freeze up and input would not be detected. The Roku remote control uses IR to control the TV, which worked absolutely fine, but it uses WiFi to control the primary device. Furthermore, the WiFi for the remote control isn't for your home network, the Roku creates its own. It's called WiFi Direct and it's awful.Not only is WiFi Direct a security vulnerability into your entire network, but it also stomps all over your main WiFi router's frequencies and causes issues for any other WiFi devices you are using, INCLUDING your Roku! We started experiencing freezes and timeouts on all devices, including the remote and Roku streaming, starting about 3 weeks ago. I had been meaning to upgrade to a Unifi AP anyway, and so partly because I assumed it was our own WiFi's fault I installed a very nice Unifi AP, which is fast and lag-free. Or was. The Roku also started behaving itself once the new WiFi was put in, but only for about 16 hours. The next day my laptop was once again struggling to connect. There were frequent disconnects. So I unplugged the Roku entirely and put it to the side. My WiFi has been fast and lag-free since.The problem is fairly straight-forward. The Unifi AP is good at channel selection and plays well with other devices. The Roku sucks at this and takes whatever channels it wants, and will change frequencies for no apparent reason. I didn't pull out an RF spectrum analyzer, but I have enough experience with WiFi to recognize this for what it is.The WiFi Direct is a terrible feature. The newer Roku models support turning it off, but my model, which must be a lower generation, does not allow it. This is bad engineering, introducing problems where none need exist. I will be using a PC running Ubuntu from now on and will never buy another dedicated streaming device. They are inflexible and insecure and when we use them we are at the mercy of the manufacturer and whatever vulnerabilities they have not addressed. It was a mistake to buy this piece of junk.UPDATE: We set up a new TV and since my earlier problems with this device I have upgraded to a good custom firewall. As soon as I plugged the Roku back in it started disrupting Wifi on other devices. The Roku firmware is fully updated. I give up on this device. I have ordered a Google Chromecast, which does not have a terrible Wifi-based remote.I broke the casing off the Roku and then broke the PCB in half with my bare hands and smashed it with a sledge. This was the most satisfying part of my entire Roku experience. Never buying a Roku again.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021

author: Amazon Customer

review_text: Roku streaming devices are wonderful in many ways. However, I’ve purchased two of these Streaming Stick-Plus’s, and I feel compelled to tell you about their less wonderful aspects: Both of the units I purchased failed pretty catastrophically. I needed their customer service to help me. And their customer service ranges from nightmarish to effectively non-existent.My first Stick+ failed after just nine days when the remote control just spontaneously completely died. I managed to get their so-called customer service to send me a replacement remote, but only after 7 completely solid, non-stop, super-ultra-nasty hours on text chat with them, including a lot of threats from me to send the whole thing back to Amazon for a refund (which is what I definitely actually should have done).My second Stick+ has overheating problems whenever the house warms up - despite good ventilation, added HDMI extender cable, etc., etc. I might possibly maybe be able to get it replaced under their supposed 1-year warranty, but, absolute best case, it would take many more hours of my time, and return shipping costs, and weeks without TV service, with no reason to expect any good outcome, just more very unpleasant, badly wasted time and money.Bottom line: You can be pretty sure you will have reliability problems and need service help with this product. But you should regard Roku’s warranty and support as non-existent, effectively just a scam, because it is. If you buy one of these units, be sure to try to flush out any problems within the first 30 days; and if you find any problems, just return it to Amazon, don’t waste your time with or expect any help from Roku.How badly can you treat your customers and still expect them to give you any credit?

author: The Tin Man

review_text: Bought this for vacations after I lost our older version (sorry hunny!).(SKIP down if you already own a Roku). All Roku devices have essentially the same setup, menu, and features. It’s very easy to get started, find apps, and navigate. It has minimal advertisements and less “in your face” suggestions as compared to an Apple TV. We are an Apple family and have switched to AppleTV twice...then promptly went back to Roku. Unfortunately Roku’s search is still a mess and more-or-less useless.The only issue we have with Our Roku’s (we use 3 different versions of them scattered through the house) is sound quality. If you stream through a high end home theater system, be aware that Roku and PLEX do not support much more than basic 5.1 channel surround. This is a problem for audiophiles but no biggie for others.(ABOUT this Roku vs others)- we bought it for traveling. It plugs into hotel TVs easily. Make sure to call the hotel’s tech support and they will register the Roku’s MAC address (found on the back of the Roku stick) so it will connect to WiFi.Finally the remote can control your TV. This has been a common complaint for some time now and I’m so happy it’s finally an included feature. This makes it easy for the kids to navigate the hotel TV and we don’t have to use the nasty public remote.The only con, and it should be expected, is speed. The Roku sticks are ALWAYS slower than the Roku boxes in our experience. If you’re going from Roku Ultra or even a Roku 3 to this you will notice everything takes about twice as long to load. Menus are still responsive and navigation is fine but actual loading times is noticeably slower.Still the best “cord cutting” device out there vs FireTV/AppleTV/etc. This is also a worthy upgrade over the older streaming stick with the improved video quality and universal remote.Update: We took it to Disney and did not have to register the MAC address. We just plugged it in, selected the WDW guest WiFi, and away we went. Bonus that WDW uses Samsung tv in their rooms and we have one at home so I didn’t even have to program the remote.
