author: Amazon Customer

review_title: Roku is okay - not everything I'd hoped, but "it'll do . . ."
review_text: Had to update my review - every day - multiple times a day - my Roku disconnects from the wifi.When I IMMEDIATELY go through the prompts - it tells my wifi strength is either Good or Excellent and lets me reconnect. Anywhere from 5 minutes to an hour later - it happens again. BEYOND frustrating.I should also note - when it happens - I'm pretty much sitting in front of TV with my laptop - connected to wifi - and my laptop connection is fine / untroubled. This fact - coupled with the fact that it immediately allows me to reconnect leads me to believe that this is a Roku issue - not an issue with my ISP or wifi signal / strength.I even followed some steps on a YouTube tutorial (basically rebooting / refreshing via Settings) and that hasn't helped.Complete waste of my money. I'm so angry with Roku right now.Like a lot of folks, I have Comcast, and I, therefore, have an insane monthly cable / internet bill. So, of course, I'm always looking for ways to cut the cord OR save some money while I'm still cable bound.I'd read an article about how some enterprising folks were using Roku and the Comcast app - which is free, right now - but it's in beta stage - to save on cable rental fees. I have 5 cable boxes (in addition to the DVR) - so I decided to give Roku a try - primarily to check out how it works as an option to get rid of my cable boxes.The set-up did NOT go off without a hitch. When I entered my network password, initially, it accepted it, and a message appeared on the screen letting me know that the system needed to re-start to complete the installation. I was thinking, 'Wow! That was insanely quick!'But then . . . when it re-started, it kept telling me that my password was incorrect. This went on for about 2.5 hours. No exaggeration. I knew my password was correct. So I just continued working (I was parked on the couch with my laptop before starting the process) and re-tried the password every 15 minutes or so, and magically, all of a sudden it accepted the password and I finished the set-up.Ultimately, I think the product is 'Okay' - but I would never put on the two TV's we use for heaviest viewing. That's because I'm not crazy about the actual interface. The TV I tried out with today is only a 42 inch - so the massive tiles (for channels) make it difficult to quickly scroll through and get to the channels you want. I tried using the voice function to quickly navigate to the channel I wanted, but that, too, proved cumbersome. For instance, (fictitious channel example - lol) let's say I searched for the 'SAL' channel. It might return results of 'SAL Channel, 'Salads television show' and 'Sal and Andy Solve True Crimes show.' So I scroll down to the 'SAL Channel', and click Ok, then it takes me another screen, where I have an option to Add the SAL Channel. Even though I've already added it. SO you click Add, then it opens.So after trying it out for a few days, I'll definitely keep it. For my office, I got some inexpensive speakers for my computer and that TV is already hooked up as a second monitor so it was just a simple matter of logging into computer and viewing my line-up.So back to what I was saying - why I would never put the Roku on a TV I use heavily - because:1) no voice remote option - no way to manually enter a channel number - so you're scrolling to get to channels which can be kinda cumbersome*2) no way to schedule a recording - you can view recordings now (I guess they won that lawsuit sling TV had against them) - but not schedule them.3) You cannot pause or rewind Live TV and I do that (A LOT)So I plan to order a two more for the other TV's, and I'll wind up purchasing another Samsung TV for the fifth television - because unlike most Smart TV's - Samsung actually has a full-on browser - so you can surf / go to any website and just login / view. It's pretty great - but that's another review . . .

If I had any complaint at all it would be that the mute button is on the side where you sometimes hit it by mistake. But honestly, that is a minor flaw. review_title: Didn’t even realize I was living in slow motion.
review_text: This thing is great. I was using my PS4 as a primary streaming device and my Netflix experience varied from “I think that’s a person but it’s hard to tell” to absolute microwaved garbage. I plugged this in and it was a night and day difference. Before Roku, I couldn’t even load a lot of shows or it took a long time to even see them in the Netflix dashboard. Now they load almost instantaneously and without any buffering mid-episode or drop in quality. I went from kind of being able to stream 1080p to easily streaming 4K UHD HDR content with no issue. I’ve been traveling for the last week or so and the Roku stick is amazing for hotels. Once connected to the hotel WiFi it’s as solid as at home and brings your ability to relax after a long day of “vacationing” to a whole other level being able to watch shows you’re actually interested in, instead of grainy hotel cable. I found that the Roku is a more powerful device than the TVs in the hotel rooms in which I stayed, meaning it can push higher quality content than crappy hotel TVs can even accept, creating a bottleneck at the tv. If you are getting tired of a slow connection or weak connectivity, get this thing and watch shows as they were meant to be watched. I didn’t even realize I was living in squalor.

review_title: Awesome, powerful device that really does have 4x the WiFi range!
review_text: Having always plugged in my MacBook Pro to whatever TV I own at the time, this wasn't a must-have product for me. It was more of a convenience, a way to watch Netflix without needing to move and connect my laptop, and anything else would be a bonus. I owned a Smart TV while living in Germany and had too many problems to justify spending the extra money on one again when I could just use my laptop. (I travel a lot and usually only live somewhere for a year or two, so the less I can spend on a TV, the better.)I must say, this little streaming stick went above and beyond my expectations. I have never written a review for a product on Amazon before, that's how much I love this thing. Being in SE Asia now, I don't have access to a lot of content, but with Netflix, Plex, and YouTube, it's already more than enough. (Having Spotify would make it perfect, but that's not Roku's fault.) And with silent listening from my phone, I can watch at any time without needing to worry about waking up anyone else in the house. (Perfect for roommates or significant others trying to sleep way earlier than you want to.)The icing on the cake, though, and what drove me to leave this review, is the advanced wireless receiver. My bedroom is down a long hallway in the house, and my laptop and iPhone have a hard time picking it up during the best of times. Not so with the Roku. I was getting HD quality content on the TV. I might even be getting better quality content in the main room where the router is because of this. Maybe I'm still so overly impressed and it's affecting my judgement, but I could swear that it never looked as good when I was using my laptop.Needless to say, I'm going to be using this for a long time to come. Maybe next time I'll spring for a 4K TV, but even without one, this thing is seriously amazing. Best value for money I've ever spent.

review_title: Superb! Order the free Roku HDMI Extender!
review_text: The Roku Streaming Stick + is almost perfect! This is my 6th Roku device. It is certainly the best. The install went very well. It correctly paired the power and volume controls with my old 32" Samsung TV.The HDMI1 port on my TV sticks straight out the back of the TV. If I hadn't ordered the free HDMI EXTENDER from Roku, the TV wouldn't have fit close to the wall. I advise everyone to order the extender. This stick is so long, it likely would not fit the main HDMI port on many TVs without the extender. It should be included in the box. Took about a week to receive after I ordered it from Roku.I used the included power adapter rather than take a chance with my TV's USB port. Many TVs were designed not to deliver enough power from the USB port.The power and volume controls on the remote work great on my TV.The WiFi reception is very good.So far, I am very pleased with the Roku Streaming Stick +!UPDATE: I have bought a 2nd Stick+ and use it on a 39” Element TV powered by the TV’s USB port. When TV is first turned on, the TV frequently doesn’t have sound. To get sound, the TV must be repeatedly turned off and on until sound returns. Problem may be caused by the Roku being plugged into HDMI 3.

review_title: Voice controls = meh & Parental Controls = c'mon man!
review_text: I'm going to go straight into pros and cons:PROS- Super Easy to install.- Voice recognition is very accurate.- Great design and I like the home screen.- Price is fair given alternatives.- Remote programmed on its own to my TV controls.CONS- The voice controls are just MEH! They don't really work within individual applications. For instance, you can't search for a certain show on Netflix while you are in Netflix. It will just search all applications for that show and then make you exit to the home screen in order to select it. It also doesn't automatically recognize whether you own the movie (say on VUDU) or not even when the account is linked.- Parental Controls are not available on the TV home screen or in settings. In fact they are VERY limited and the ONLY way to block purchases is to set up a pin on your Roku website account. I mean c'mon man, its hard enough as it is to keep my 3 year old from ordering accidentally, don't make it harder! *This is the prime reason for the 3-star rating (no pun intended).SUMMARYI am not impressed. I want to like it, but find myself just a little annoyed. Now that I have it all set up, I will most likely keep it, but who knows. I certainly like my friend's Firestick better. I'm only 1 person, but that's my $.02!

author: The Wizard

review_title: Pros & Cons of ROKU vs Firestick
review_text: I did not rate the Voice or Alexa integration because I do not use either.After using exclusively firesticks for two years, I decided to add a ROKU because I’d discovered that ROKU supports multiple apps that carry free movie serials, while on firestick those same public domain serials are behind pay walls. I have multiple HDMI slots, so why not use both?The reason ROKU gets 4 stars instead of 5, is because their registration is a royal pain. I can understand why some people appear to give up and return the device. I also would not have given it even 4 stars during my couple weeks, because you separately have to order (for free from ROKU) an HDMI extender which is not included in this box. Then once you do get everything working it takes active exploring to learn one’s way around and make ROKU worth your effort.The major problem with ROKU is their registration process. You can’t use the device until you register it. It only recognizes certain email carriers, and if you’re not using one of them, tough. I wanted to register my device with the same email address I use with my firestick, but no. Luckily I had a gmail account, and ROKU accepted that.The other immediately off-putting aspect of a ROKU versus Firestick that took me a week to overcome is its upfront interface. Firestick’s interface is like being inside an app/streaming service already – it is far better organized and you can save shows/movies from multiple streaming services to a single watchlist. I scarcely ever go into Amazon’s fire tv app itself as the interface above it is so good. ROKU on the other hand essentially has no watchlist sitting above the individual streaming service apps. You have to count on those services having watch lists themselves, and some do not. On ROKU, to find interesting apps having content you want, you must be willing to work and explore.But if you’re willing to explore, that’s when ROKU’s advantages shine. ROKU has literally thousands of available apps/streaming channels, many more than the firestick (most prominent amongst those unique to ROKU being Peacock and Vice TV). Apps on the firestick appear to be more professional/commercial, while on ROKU everything exists down to what I’d label “amateur hour” apps, which while not laid out professionally, are still offering public domain material for free with zero ads. Older content that on a firestick you’d have to pay MUBI or “Best TV Ever” to watch, can be found for free on ROKU.Many streaming apps that exist for both devices, do not work the precise same way in both (though a few do). Some work better on ROKU vs Firestick, and vice-versa. VEVO is my favorite free music app on Firestick; it’s version on ROKU I find unwatchable. IMDb & Pluto TV I cannot stand going into on Firestick (instead I use the firestick’s interface above them), but on ROKU getting into their On Demand works great. Navigation within DistroTV is far smoother in ROKU than Firestick. TUBI works identically in both. Ironically, the side-loaded Peacock app on Firestick has a slight improvement over the legit Peacock app on ROKU (on Firestick, Peacock’s “View All” is on the immediate left, while on ROKU you need to scroll to the far right to find it).Lastly, the picture and sound quality on ROKU is observably superior to firestick (to be forthright, my firestick is 2 years old, my ROKU is new, so there’s that). One negative on ROKU vs Firestick, when I’m travelling then return home, the Firestick remembers my prior WiFi setups, while ROKU seems only able to retain the setting for a single location, requiring me to re-enter my home set up once I’m back.I now switch between the two now depending on what I want to watch. An advantage of having both is that if the two are making different offers for the same streaming service I’m interested in, I can pick the better of the two.Doug Wheeler

author: Devin W

review_text: Recently we decided to cut the cord and as long-time Roku users we discovered that our old Roku would not be capable of doing the live streaming we would need to access services like Hulu Live or DirecTV Now. After doing some research and based on Amazon customer and outside reviews we decided to upgrade to the Roku Streaming Stick+. After a rocky installation process that took a couple of days we finally got it to work. It was faster than our old Roku and the picture quality was superior. Unfortunately, this did not last long. Like many other reviewers, after about two months (a month past the return window date), we began to have issues. At first we began to experience constant buffering every time we tried to watch a program. And eventually we could not get the programming to start at all and got messages about our connection to the internet and about "weak signal strength."And of course whatever the trouble was it always came back to assigning the blame to OUR router, OUR SmartTV, and/or OUR internet provider. We tried everything we could think of including restarting everything, reinstalling everything, and checking the status of our router and our signal (according to the Roku itself, our wifi and internet signals were good to excellent). We went through this over and over again to no avail. One of Roku's recommendations was to mitigate the interference between our router and the Roku stick by having them in close proximity to each other with no walls in between. While our router and Roku were not in the same room, they were in sight of each other. And if that were the problem, why did this arrangement work fine with our old Roku and with this one for the first two months? On the other hand, one of the selling points of the Stick+ was that it would work with a less-than-ideal signal.Finally, after several days of trying and failing to get access to any programming using the stick, we put the unit back in the box and reinstalled our old Roku (which worked just fine).Some avenues of exploration that Roku might consider concern the Stick itself. Our old Roku box is relatively cool to the touch. On the other hand, when the Stick's power cord is plugged into the wall the unit gets extremely hot (even when it is not plugged into the TV). Also, on our Samsung SmartTV the HDMI socket is relatively high on the back of the set and even though the Stick "clicked" into place the downward stress with the added weight of the USB power cable pulling on it might have had the effect of weakening the connection. The old expression "it hangs like a dog's ear" comes to mind. At one point I even used tape to affix the cables to the back of the TV in an effort to relieve the stress, but like everything else we tried it only worked briefly. As a last resort we requested the free HDMI extender cable that Roku offers in case the Stick+ does not fit your HDMI socket and it did strengthen the connection, but it did not solve the overall problem. We still kept getting messages about signal strength and we still could not successfully access programming. It's as though we had come full circle from the early days of TV when someone in the family had to hold the rabbit ears to get a clear signal. Nowadays you need a volunteer from the audience to hold the Stick in place while wearing an oven mitt.Maybe there just some inherent problems with the Stick+. Six hundred negative reviews (as of this review) should not be ignored.

author: Theo

review_title: Great streaming even on slow connection
review_text: Here are my experiences with the 2017 Streaming Stick+ Roku.First let me specify my setup. I have a slow 2.4 (typically) Mbps Internet connection. Previously I was using a Panasonic BMP110 Blu-Ray player for what little streaming I did. That was mainly used for trying out the Vudu free movies. It was marginal; with my slow connection, sometimes it would work pretty well, and sometimes it would complain and give up intermittently.I have a Yamaha VX-477 Receiver.And it all feeds into a 2011 Panasonic Plasma TV.Setup:It probably isn’t very important, but the remote uses AAA batteries, not AA. I slapped in a couple of Eneloops and it’s happy.I see people complaining about having to give credit card information to activate their Roku. This is not necessary. Go to the page made for this option: my dot roku dot com/signup/nocc, and you can create a Roku account without entering any credit card or PayPal information. I know, because I did it.If you’re wondering about using the Roku with an A/V receiver, that works. I plugged the stick into one of the HDMI inputs on my Yamaha, and it works just fine. 4K wouldn’t cut it, because my receiver doesn’t really support it. But my TV isn’t 4K anyway, so that isn’t a problem.Some people are complaining about HDCP errors. This is probably because they’re trying to use 4K video on a TV that doesn’t support HDCP 2.2. My five year old TV works just fine, because it’s only 1080p. If you want to see 4K video, make sure your TV really supports HDCP2.2. And you need an HDMI connection that also supports HDCP 2.2. On some TVs that’s only one port.If 1080p24 is important to you, Roku says only the 4K devices can do it. I had to turn it off; when the movie would break for commercials, the receiver usually flaked out. I would have to switch HDMI inputs on the receiver, then switch back to the original. The guide says the screen may flash black; mine mainly went to snow, and wouldn’t recover. So I’m doing without 1080p24. It might work better for people who plug it directly into the TV; I didn’t try that.The specs talk about 802.11ac, but it works just fine on my old router without ac.To set this thing up, look at the Quick Start Guide, or just go to the Roku page about your specific device. Basically I just plugged the stick into an HDMI input, plugged the power adapter into my UPS, and connected the cables. It started right up.I haven’t tried different models, so I can’t offer a comparison. But the Streaming Stick+ works great.First you have to pick a wireless network, and provide the password. Then the stick downloads the latest firmware.When it restarted, mine didn’t connect the first time, even though it indicated it still remembered the password. After sitting for a while with a spinning wheel, it finally gave a 014.40 error, and suggested some alternatives. I just unplugged the power cable and plugged it back in. It restarted, and everything was fine.It will go through a few screens, and give you a four letter code. Go back to the page you end up at after creating your account online, or the page they refer you to. Enter the code, and you’re all set. You can select some channel options. Your stick is now busy setting up channels.And things seem to be working great. It does fine showing a movie in standard definition. It has trouble with the commercials; I wonder if they’re a higher definition. But it gets over it quickly.Things like rewind and fast forward are far better than on my old Blu-Ray player.So far I’m just using things that are free. Look around online at the Roku site, and you can see what’s available.So in summary:This thing works surprisingly well with a slow connection. You don’t get 4K video, but it looks pretty good in old-fashioned 1080p (which is probably really a lot less, as in standard def upscaled to 1080).It works plugged into a receiver that then separates out the audio, and passes the video on to the TV.It works with old routers that don’t have 802.11ac. And it works with new routers that have 5GHz ac.You can create an account without providing any credit card information.I recommend this device to anyone that needs a streaming connection.

review_title: A few more features, and fantastic performance improvement over previous generation Roku
review_text: So here is the deal. I already have a Roku Streaming Stick 3600R (2016 version) in our family room. We liked it so much that we wanted our kids to have it for their play area TV, which was closer to the router. Since the family room now needed a new streaming device, I decided to go with the next logical step, the Roku Streaming Stick+ 3810.I am not new to the Roku experience and interface. It was still very snappy. The great content apps were still there. It's basically waiting for me to do a TV upgrade to 4K, which I don't know when it's going to happen. :)I also did discover that I can actually turn on/off the power to my Sony sound bar and also control its volume using only the Roku remote. This makes it very convenient.To feel good about this upgrade, I decided to do several tests related to the temperature, Wi-Fi signal (both using Roku secret menus) and then a speed test using Netflix. I know the Netflix test is not a pure speed test because it uses the Netflix servers, but it's an acceptable indicator for me.Please keep in mind that this is not a scientific test. It's more of a test to check for systematic changes between the two Rokus given other fixed factors. I did all testing within the span of 1-2 hours so I hope no major changes were introduced that affected the tests.Test Configuration (things that did not change during testing): - I did *not* change any advanced default settings in the Roku devices (e.g. interference mitigation, power, etc.) - For audio/video, Roku devices were connected via HDMI to a Sony sound bar HT-CT380, *not* directly into the TV. Both the sound bar and TV support only 1080p, not 4K. - For power, Roku devices were connected to Dish Network Hopper 3 receiver's USB port, which is nice because it is on all the time, whether Hopper is powered on or in standby. - For Wi-Fi, Roku devices were connected wirelessly to a Netgear Nighthawk R7000 (with custom Tomato Shibby firmware) which supports both bands: 2.4 and 5.0 GHz.Test Results*** Roku Streaming Stick (3600) ***Temperature: 74 C2.4 GHz Signal strength: 252.4 GHz Antenna 1: 292.4 GHz Antenna 2: 32Glitch/sec: 385.0 GHz Signal strength: 195.0 GHz Antenna 1: 175.0 GHz Antenna 2: 19Glitch/sec: 32.4 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 14.87 Mbps5.0 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 15.63 Mbps*** Roku Streaming Stick+ (3810) ***Temperature: 97 C2.4 GHz Signal strength: 212.4 GHz Antenna 1: 322.4 GHz Antenna 2: 34Glitch/sec: 1775.0 GHz Signal strength: 285.0 GHz Antenna 1: 345.0 GHz Antenna 2: 32Glitch/sec: 02.4 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 35.58 Mbps5.0 GHz Netflix Connection Speed: 75.13 MbpsConclusions: - Roku 3810 runs about ~30% hotter than the Roku 3600. I hope it's still within acceptable range. I did not receive any warnings or anything during use. - With Roku 3810, 2.4 GHz overall Signal Strength decreased by ~16% compared to Roku 3600. - With Roku 3810, 5.0 GHz overall Signal Strength improved by ~47% compared to Roku 3600. - With Roku 3810, 2.4 Ghz Netflix connection speed improved by an impressive ~139% compared to Roku 3600. - With Roku 3810, 5.0 Ghz Netflix connection speed improved by an incredible ~380% compared to Roku 3600.Comments: - I noticed in one of the tests that the while the Antennas (1 and 2) signal strengths were higher, the overall Signal Strength was lower. Perhaps the overall Signal Strength takes into account other factors such as glitch/sec, interference, etc.? I am not really sure. - Even though 2.4 GHz signal was poorer with the new Roku, I still got faster speeds with Netflix. This tells me that not only the antennas are different, but perhaps the Wi-Fi chipset is improved or something. - In general, using 2.4 GHz band produced way more glitches per second compared to 5.0 GHz, so in my situation, I recommend/prefer using the 5.0 GHz band, especially considering the speed test results in Netflix.Overall, I feel happy about the experience.

review_title: Occasionally you find a True Win!! :)
review_text: I'm one of those types who hates paying for Cable. My kids, however, want *ONLY* CN and Boomerang; mom ONLY wants Food or Travel Network; etc.. For years I was looking for a way to cut my cable bill - no joy... until today. This looked too good to be true. When I first bought this, I started out disappointed. The video quality was excellent, install easy, no additional Roku hidden fees, connects to Amazon Prime, NetFlix, etc., but when I first hooked it up Thursday, the Roku channels weren't all they were cracked up to be. However, after a little on-line research this morning, I stumbled onto Slack and a HDMI antenna. Signed up on-line for $20/month (+5 per additional channel set) on Slack and broadcast HDTV, I was able to get *all* the channels we normally get through cable! Kids have been watching all morning long and COULDN'T TELL THE DIFFERENCE!!! Now I can cut back to basic Internet for $30/month, etc. True happiness. DISLIKES: It's not a seamless experience - you can't pick 'channels' and surf them up and down. The remotes do have jump to buttons for Sling, NetFlix, Hulu, and Vue - just not the same. As an upgrade, I hope they add a 'channel surfing' feature where you can select which channels you want to surf.

review_title: Get the Stick: Avoid the Ultra
review_text: I originally got the Ultra, but after months of frustration with HDMI connectivity issues with the Ultra, i decided to get the stick in order to avoid connecting with an HDMI cable. It worked. The Roku stick works great. The Roku interface is the most intuitive....much better than Apple TV (which goes for cool rather than intuitive) or various smart TV interfaces which are generally awful. Roku is able to get all the apps you want. I have yet to find a channel it doesn't get.As to the Ultra, I would avoid it. It works for a while and then out of nowhere it tells you your HDMI cable is not compatible. You need version 2.2. I kept buying new HDMI cables to meet the stated requirements. But it was always the same story. After a while the Ultra would reject my new cable and refuse to show the streaming video I was trying to watch. It did this on YouTube TV, HBO, Showrime and Amazon Prime channels. I changed screen resolution settings, rebooted, reset...nothing worked as the Ultra is a flawed design.So save youself the headache and buy the Roku stick, which works very well.

review_text: This is our 4th Roku, and by far the least reliable and most annoying. It constantly either reboots itself, or (less frequently) randomly factory re-sets itself, thus prompting us to re-download our apps and re-enter username and passwords for everything. This once happened three times in a single week. Sit down to dinner, fire up the Roku and... Roku logo and first-time setup screen again. Ridiculous. And it's not as if the USB power was interrupted as others have suggested. It has its own USB wall outlet, and tried every HDMI port on my TV. The re-booting thing has always existed with Roku devices and, honestly, this shouldn't be an issue after half a decade of supposed 'improvements.' I thought the latest Roku would be a nice alternative to my smart TV's uncontrollable home screen advertising on my Android Sony Bravia, but nope. Both are littered with ads. So what's the point of having multiple streaming devices if they're all spammy and slow? They all suck. It's infuriating that you can't disable the advertising panel on the right side of the Roku home screen, which only seems to recommend extreme right-wing fake news channels like Newsmax, or Tucker Carlson's BS show on Fox. Seriously? Roku should be paying me at this point for all the inconveniences, not the other way around. I don't know if the answer is to try another one, or to switch to a FireStick. Either way, I don't even use my new Roku stick anymore, I unplugged it and stuck it in a drawer and went back to using my smart TV for my streaming subscriptions.*4/15/22 UPDATE*Tried using it again, but the Roku stick doesn't even boot anymore. Hard reset does nothing. Never makes it past start-up splash screen. It's completely bricked. Wish I could get my money back for this POS. I wanna set this thing on fire, film it, and upload the video to YouTube where my hate for this device will live forever. Without a doubt the worst $40+ purchase I've ever made. I'd give it zero stars if possible.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2021

review_text: My wife had enjoyed our original Roku unit for several years but had to start unplugging then plugging it in to get it to work. I looked online and thought I would "upgrade" to the Roku stick. It showed up promptly (thanks Amazon!) and the installation should have been a piece of cake. It wasn't. The software kept getting stuck on the installation. After power the unit and the tv down and up several times it finally went through. Now we're getting to the sad part.All remotes now a days have 4 directional navigation buttons and the right arrow on this unit wouldn't work unless you pushed REAL hard and repeatedly. Is it too much to ask for a new product to work like its supposed to? This new remote also has a cheaper, thinner non-ergonomic feel to it and is designed to be operated with your thumb. If you have to use your index finger, for instance, when lifting pointing the unit then one of your other fingers will always press the volume mute button. This is simply a bad design.When I use a service or product I think the provider should excel at what they do: a burger joint should make amazing burgers and stop chasing chicken n shrimp, a lamp should light when I press the button and a remote control should be intuitive, easy to hold and operate. Sorry Roku, you struck out on this one.

review_text: Our old Roku player quit working after about 3 years. It kept giving me a purple screen with error codes. I contacted support and they said that I would need to replace it. I didn't feel that a product working 3 years would need to be replaced, but apparently Roku products do. I figured I would replace it, because I like the Roku Interface and when it worked I didn't really have any issues. We got a new TV, so I figured I would buy the streaming stick+ now that we could enjoy 4k. After a few months the product said it couldn't connect to the internet. When I look at the status of the internet connection it says good. I moved the Roku Streaming Stick+ to the TV next to the WiFi router and still have issues connecting to the internet. When I run the check internet status it says it can't connect. So I had Roku forget the Wifi, and reconnected to the internet. It connected back to the internet and said the connection was good, but then it says I have a weak internet connection again. I contacted support again, and they sent me a HDMI extender, which makes zero sense, because I don't understand how or why a HDMI extender would help with my WiFi connection. I'm reaching out to Roku again, but I'm guessing they will suggest I purchase a new roku product. I will never recommend Roku to anyone, and will never purchase any products from them again.If they won't stand by their products why should I?
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2019

review_title: 720 and 1080 would not work at all with HDCP1.4
review_text: I gave this stick 4 stars on the basis of it working with 4K. My Vizio 65" screen had to small of a indentation where HDMI1 was located for the Roku to fit, so I was temporarily forced to use a side port HDMI4, which only supports HDCP1.4. No matter how hard I tried, or what I set the Roku to for display (tried auto, 720 and 1080) it would bring up everything fine, menus, channels, etc....until it tried play video, in which case, it would purple screen with an HDCP error and emit a loud tone from the TV requiring reboot. This was tried several times, in various ways. Never could get it to work. Once I received my 1.5" 4K compatable HDMI extension cable, and plugged the Roku into the 4K HDCP2.2 port, then it finally worked after about two attempts with a purple screen. If you are looking for 4K, and have the time to spend tinkering and trying different things, then you may like this. If you have no interest in 4K, or do not have a 4K TV, avoid this one.Added: 7/2018 - After buying a Marantz 4K HDCP2.2 AVR and plugging this into it, along with a 4K Tivo Bolt, everything worked fine and it streamed 4K video from the internet just fine. I attempted to stream a 4K Atmos file from my computer server (i7 with Gig ethernet), and the flle would play about 2 minutes and then fail with an bandwidth error. The file was 12Mb/s video, plus audio. Tried 5GHz and 2.4GHz with same results using the Plex App. Switched to the Tivo, which also has the Plex app, but is hooked up through ethernet, and the file played fine. So apparently, the wireless speed of this device isnt quite up to streaming 4K blu ray quality video (the signal was excellent and the Roku was 2 ft from the router). If I had to do it over, I think I would pay the extra and get the external non-stick HD version, with ethernet connectivity. All in all though, Roku is still the best platform for streaming I have experienced.Update: Unit was only used one or two hours, a couple times a month. Lasted until today, and will now not accept remote control commands from original or new remote. Hitting the trash bin. Save your money and get the better version with a fan. This one overheats badly.

review_text: If you are considering getting a Roku device this information is for you. I got into the “World of Roku” in Sep 2020. Started with the Roku Streaming Stick+ on Sep 8, 2020. Everything was fine for a while but then in December Roku stopped allowing the Spectrum app to download. I then got a Roku Ultra 2020 on Jan 13, 2021 thinking that I could download the Spectrum app on it. Nope. Then a month or so later I could no longer get FoxNews or FoxBusiness. During this 4-month period of time I was slowly understanding what Roku is and how it works. It appears that Roku allows apps like the Charter Spectrum app to download onto the Roku device in exchange for a fee paid by Charter Spectrum to Roku. If Roku asks for an unreasonable fee which Charter Spectrum refuses to pay Roku can block the download of the Charter Spectrum app. If the Charter Spectrum app cannot download on your Roku device, and that includes Roku televisions, you are then unable to view the programs that you used to be able to view. I got fed up with the squabbling. I quit using my Roku Streaming Stick+. I returned the Roku Ultra to the vendor that I bought it from. I then went to my local Spectrum Store and got a Spectrum Cable Box to self-install (and I’m not a tecky). It’s small – about 10 x 10 x 3. It will now cost me $6 per month to have “hassle free” TV. Oh, and by the way, if you try to talk with Roku on the phone you get a recording telling you that due to the Pandemic support techs are not available. The recording directs you to online FAQs etc. Now you decide. Due you want to be the victim of squabbles or do you want easy TV. Your choice. My Roku Streaming Stick+ is for sale on Craigslist and eBay. Nobody wants it. Does that tell you something?
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2021

review_title: The best streaming stick for your money.
review_text: I've had Apple TVs from the first gen to the latest 4k one. For around $50 this Roku Streaming Stick+ is the best option for your money and this supports all current video and audio formats (4k, UHD, HDR, Dolby Atmos etc.). I added this to a Denon AVR-X4400H and it switches on the AVR and TV (Samsung UN65JU7500FXZA) and controls the volume as well. The only 1 remote I need and the only 1 streaming stick I use, although I have Apple TV 4th gen and Samsung Smart interface as well. This has way more apps and choices compared to Apple TV and the only thing this doesn't have is games (which I don't play it on Apple TV anyway).Another reason to get this in a bedroom or guest room is that you can access the Xfinity Stream app and all your subscriptions plus live TV through it rather than paying $10/month for a cable box to Comcast. That's ROI within 5 months. I have this in my main TV set in the living room and in the master bedroom. Also have a cheap TCL Roku TV in the guest bedroom. No issues activating unlike some reviews that mentioned it here while owning multiple Roku devices.Only cons I can think of -1) The voice recognition and search functionality needs major enhancement and doesn't work all that well.2) The remote acts up sometimes and doesn't control the TV/AVR and I have to reset the Roku device (others have mentioned this as well)Overall - I really want to give this 5 stars, 5 stars for the price, 5 stars for the app store, 5 stars for the functionality, 5 stars for formats supported, etc. etc. I'm just taking 1 star away for the minor niggles with remote and universal / voice search.

review_title: Great product! And no you don't have to pay to have more than 2 on your account....
review_text: This is a great streaming device and the third Roku that I have so far (still using all 3 just fine) Let me start by first saying that there is a very popular highly trending negative rating from Nov 2018 here on Amazon warning people that if you try to add more than 2 Roku devices onto your account, Roku will insist on starting to charge you for a Premium account (or something.) This is false. The first photo I included here is my account showing all 3 of my Roku devices on my one account, zero charged, still free. So don't believe that review. The only thing i can think of is that maybe the author of the negative review got scammed and clicked on a spoofing/phishing website that tried to scam her out of money. Either way, rest easy, it's false, you don't get charged for having 3 devices and here's your proof. The second picture is my connection to the TV. I used the direct to TV method (powered by TV, not using electrical outlet.) You can see that the Roku itself is plugged in to the HDMI-3 port and the short black power wire is going into the USB port labeled "USB (HDD 5V 1A)" just above it. That's it. Easy-peasey. If you have a TV with connections that can support this set-up, it doesn't get much easier. It fired right up, linked right up to the Wi-Fi extender I already had right in the same room. Signal rating is "excellent." The third and final picture is the home screen after a few minutes of churning away adding/installing all the apps. All fired up and ready to go now. Very fast and robust navigation from app to app and using the apps. Way faster than my two older ones (Roku-3 from 2013, and Roku Express from 2017) I don't have a big body of work using the voice command remote. It's my first one, the older ones don't have that. I tried it once, I said something like "Open Netflix app" and it did just that, brought me right to the Netflix app and opened it. Pretty cool I guess. Granted it's only been a couple days but so far it's been great, as have the other two other Roku units in the house. Overall great deal. Very happy and would not hesitate to recommend it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020

review_title: Roku just isn't what it was
review_text: I've owned them since the very first "roku netflix player". I've had boxes, sticks, ultras, etc. Maybe 10-12 of them in total over the years.I bought this stick+ for an advertised 3 month CBS all access deal for free, which wasn't much less than I paid for the stick. Humorously, I needed another remote control and the stick+ with remote was $10 more than just the remote.The deal had to be activated by 4/5. Its now 3/31. Won't work. Roku advertised this special offer for months, and still has it on their site, but now it says you have to click through their site to a retailer to get it. It didn't say that last month when I bought it. They refuse to budge.Along the way, I've found their tech support to be bad when it used to be pretty good. I've also had their top of the line Ultra's simply not work properly with my off brand Sony and Samsung tv's (sorry, had to toss out a pun) giving me errors, the remotes stopping working altogether, various streaming issues where I could literally unplug the roku and plug a fire tv 4k box into the same cable and it'd work fine."Its a problem with your network, cables or tv".No Roku, you simply make some problematic products these days, have made the activation process onerous (MUST provide name, credit card, address, phone number, birthdate and gender), and you don't honor your deals.Fun part is, those early roku's I bought still worked fine, as did their remotes, albeit very slowly when I checked them out and factory reset them before recycling them a few years ago.

review_title: Internet Cap from Provider? Want to Stream TV? Be careful.
review_text: Recently decided to try and ditch the cable bill and use a tv streaming service (yttv). One big thing to note is that the power button only turns the tv on/off (via IR). If you've got a 1080p stream going and push that power button, you will continue to eat up your internet bandwidth to the tune of up to 50GB/night. I came to this realization a bit too late. All you have to do is be sure to hit the "home" button before shutting off the tv. Easy to remember, extremely difficult to put into practice with a revolving door of toddlers and guests accessing the tv.A second option would be to power the device via USB power from the tv, but this means a reboot of the device every time the tv is power cycled - this is far from ideal when considering boot time plus remote pairing time. Far too long for my taste.I much prefer this unit to the fire stick that has screen after screen of Amazon content and no (official) yttv support. The interface is the best I've used on a streaming device (fire stick, roku, shield tv).I'm removing a star based on two things:1) the remote interface for a consumer looking to stream tv. An option to trigger a "home" button push with every power button push would be super... or hold the home button for some time to trigger the IR to shut off the tv... Just something to couple those two buttons somehow. Maybe even put the device into a standby mode/home screen based on HDMI CEC when the tv shuts off. I just hate that a tv power button was included on the remote that doesn't function the way a traditional tv power button functions.2) no sound bar volume support. Tvs get flatter, speakers get worse necessitating external sound, and this remote cannot support it. Boo. Fire stick does.Regarding #1, Sure, the tv streaming app could include a timeout option, but the ideal scenario to me is to stop all streaming when I command the display off. Certainly music streamers would not prefer such a feature, so to me, the ingredients lead me to believe this should be an option.Very good product, just not very good for me.I literally cannot afford to use this device to stream tv due to this functionality combined with the occupants of my home.

review_text: Sorry Fire TV stick. Time to move over and make room for Roku+We cut cable about a year ago and have been using the Fire TV stick ever since. After losing both remotes and having to use the app on our phones to control it, we were getting sort of annoyed. On top of that, the fire tv was so incredibly glitchy and slow, it wasn't even worth it to try to watch anymore. It needed to be unplugged/reset every day.Here comes a Black friday deal on the Roku+ and I have to give it a try.Set up was a breeze. We put it in a room far from the wi-fi router, but it still connected seamlessly with no problems. It is lightning fast when booting up and moving from app to app. Like a night and day difference from the Fire. The included remote is easy to use and I like the volume control that's also included. Plus, it has all the apps we were used to with our old stick - plenty of cable TV streaming apps (ask a generous relative/neighbor for their cable login info and you're good to go) in addition to the Roku TV channel and lots of other content as well.Overall, I am very pleased. I am planning to buy a second one to replace the fire tv stick we had in the other room. The speediness and vast array of content is totally worth it.

review_text: Stuff I like: Super Simple to use, supports 4K with HDR, much faster than previous models, can be plugged into a USB port on the television for power with the included cable, (preventing the need to buy the little $5 stick-to-USB cable to avoid using the AC cord), remote as always is so simple with only a few buttons and this one controls the TV on/off as well as the volume - though I still have four remotes for my TV! :(Stuff I don't like: Does not support Dolby Vision, remote has the sponsered one-touch pre-programmed buttons with channels most of us have no need whatsoever forI do use three streaming platforms on one television - Roku, Chromecast, and Fire Stick.Roku is by far the better of the three and this is my second Roku streamer. The simplicity is what gives Roku the edge over the others. Even though I've only used the iPhone app for my pre-existing Roku, the included remote is simple with only a few buttons and no clutter. I do wish the "included pre-programmed" buttons, like the one-touch Netflix, Sling, Hulu, and Vue, (what the heck is VUE???) buttons were not there and instead we were given the option to add our own one-touch favorites instead of letting those companies pay Roku for the privilege. It's just wasted space on the remote, except maybe for Netflix. Roku could have used one of those buttons for a much needed mute button for the volume.My favorite for supporting Roku over the others, and I'm sure many agree, is the extremely simple home screen. Many web review sites say it could be called "dated" but in this case, it's welcomed and Roku's biggest asset. It's too simple and attractive. My favorite positive Roku has over the others is there is little to no bias whatsoever on the home screen as the others can add so much clutter, advertising, and pushing their sponsored marketing stuff on you. I also like the idea that I can plug the power for the stick directly into an unused USB port on the TV to avoid using the included AC power cord and adapter. Our TVs today have enough unsightly wires in the back from stuff as it is!My personal biggest negative with the Roku Streaming Stick + is it does not support Dolby Vision, only HDR10. I can't figure Roku out on this, the days of regular 4K are far behind us and a televison without both HDR10 and Dolby Vision should ** never ** be considered if you're really into televison specs and display quality. Thankfully my Vizio supports both Dolby Vison and HDR10 on Chromecast. The lack of Dolby Vision is why I gave this review 4 stars instead of 5. It would be nice if the remote would control my Vizio's input options in addition to the volume and power on/off buttons allowing me to put my Vizio remote away.Overall, for the price, quality, and features, this is an excellent streamer I highly recommend.

I have to turn it off and on, sometimes unplug it because it is frozen and won't do anything. I just turned the sound off for the button because I read that could cause it, but I just did that, so not sure if that is a good fix. When it works, it is great. I will update in a few weeks.I was going to wait to update, but I just got so frustrated trying to get this thing to work I had to downgrade my rating. I have tried everything to get this thing to work. I restarted it, unplugged and restarted it multiple times, and no luck. There are a lot of people having issues like I am having, just do an internet search on Roku freezing.Okay, after trying for 45 minutes to get this to work I found a website that said to refresh the remote. I had no clue I would have to wipe the remote clear and then pair it again with the stick. Finally working, but it will be interesting to see how often I will have to do this.Absolute junk!!!!!!!!

review_title: Roku will decide which apps you get to use
review_text: I put Roku sticks on all of my Samsung "smart" TVs because I was sick of dealing with slow updates and lack of apps. My apps on Roku are kept up to date, but they still don't get all the features that Android TV devices get. I have 5 Rokus, an Amazon Fire Stick, TiVo Stream, Apple TV, and Chromecast. I went with all Roku because their apps are the most up to date and the user interface is easy. After playing around with the Fire Stick and TiVo (both Android), I've found that those apps are just as up to date or more and I can side load any app I want.Roku and YouTube are in a heated battle right now and it looks like Roku might block YouTube because they can't come to an agreement. I don't want a device that leverages its large user base to force providers into contracts. I'm not a fan of the user interfaces on TiVo or Fire Stick, but at least they don't block me from side loading apps that aren't in the app stores.My advice to you is to find a pure Android TV device. They aren't locked down to weird interfaces like Amazon & TiVo and they won't ever block you from putting any app you want on them. They might cost a little more up front because they aren't making more off of you with tons of ads, but in the long run, they don't play politics and they don't have a say in which apps you get to have access to.I'll try to remember to update this when I find a good Android device. I've heard really good things about Shield, but it's pretty expensive to add to ask of my TVs.

review_title: Unit Failed in 6 months, worst customer service ever
review_text: The unit quit working after 6 months. Could not sync the remote to the stick. After troubleshooting with the tech by phone it was determined the unit was bad and an RMA warranty was issued. The unit was returned by Express Mail and arrived within four days of the RMA being issued. Then a whole series of canned emails began, most ending with the question had this been resolved. I kept answer4ing no, not until a replacement unit was shipped. More canned emails. After about 10 days of this I was able to locate a customer service phone number (not on Roku’s website) and called them. I was told the status was they have the RMA, it takes about 10-14 days to ship a replacement depending on the warehouse but that I would b e getting a replacement soon. This seems to be ridiculous amount of time for a warranty replacement. A week later I get an email requesting a tracking number for the original return. Well I had been in temporary quarters for several weeks and had now relocated and frankly did not store the USPS receipt safely as Roku said they had received the unit. Called Roku again and explained all of this to an agent who spoke poor English. Said he would do nothing without a tracking number. Asked to speak to someone who could resolve issue or to a supervisor. The agent just kept repeating without the tracking number he would do nothing and would not allow me to speak with anyone else. I finally gave up. I will now go with Amazon Fire-stick. This is the worst customer service I have ever encountered in either my professional or consumer roles.

review_text: I've been using the Wii for about ten years, but they got rid of YouTube a few months ago, and now are getting rid of Netflix, so it's useless technology unless you have old games. The Roku is great for streaming, and no, you do not need to add a credit card as others have mentioned. You only need to add steaming services that you already have, OR use the free channels, as there are several.The Talk to Search is really awesome on the remote control, but it doesn't always recognize what you are saying. The downside is that it only searches all of Roku, not specific channels. For example, if you search YouTube for "90's Music," it will search the Roku channels for it. You can't search within the channel itself using the voice option. It also doesn't always understand very well, even when you're speaking clearly. You can keep repeating it and nothing will populate, but then when you type to search, what the Roku just said was not there by voice, suddenly appears. Very glitchy.There are times that it will freeze on the home welcome screen as well, but turning it off and on helps. Overall, those are the only complaints I've encountered. Setting it up was easy.

review_text: Let me say that I have 2 other Roku's that are fantastic and have never had any issues with them. Bought a new TV in July and was excited about the fact that Roku makes this stick that can handle 4K and HDR. Over the past 5 months my excitement has faded. I, like several others, get the HDCP warning on a regular basis and the worst part is that it happens when I'm trying to load non-4K apps. After calling Roku customer service in November they sent me an HDMI extender, which did absolutely nothing. Recently there is a new issue...the remote keeps un-pairing from the Roku. Customer service has finally agreed to replace it since it's still under warranty but I must pay shipping to return the defective one to them. The two stars applies to the device and their customer service.UPDATE 6/5/19 - downgraded to one star due to the fact that the replacement Roku is just as bad as the original. It also has a whole new set of issues including constantly losing connection with my network, unpairing from the remote which doesn't work half the time, audio issues, and failing for no apparent reason...and once in bright red letters on the screen was a message saying the Roku was overheating...unplug it! I have come to know not to wait until the show I want to watch is starting because it can take up to 20 minutes of restarting/repairing to get the thing to work. I'll be throwing this out & replacing with something else. It's junk & I do not want to deal with Roku "customer service" again.

review_title: Product, website, and support is awful.
review_text: Shame on me for letting this product sit around for a couple of months before I got around to installing it. Decided to do this on Dec 6th, 2020 on a rainy day. Instructions make it look easy. And it was at first.....long story short, when going through the setup of the product you enter an e-mail address that sends you an activation link. First time failed? Second time was a success. Went through the process and got the congratulations page. Sitting on the TV was the page that simply showed my e-mail th link would be sent to and a * option that gave yo the option to reset the device. Also, it stated the link would expire in 15 minutes. Ok. Great. I completed the process as stated above and finished out.........now what? Page is still shown on the TV stating it would send me a link. Do I turn it on and turn it off. The * option, just gave me options to reset the deive to factory defaults or restart the device. So, I cut it off vis the power button on the remote and upon starting back up it either goes back to the page showing a link will be sent or starts the process all over again. It's stuck in a loop. What's worse is the website sucks too. Go to the roku support website and it asks for the category of support needed and then the model number and...........no continue button, no page refresh for that model, nothing. Page just looks like it was not finished by the developers. How could it suck this bad? Oh, and if you finally find the Roku support number you get a recording saying they no longer offer phone support due to Covid-19. They don't offer chat support either. Looks like I will have to choose another product to cut the cord. Obviously for Roku to be aorund as long as they have they have got to have some good products......or just nose dived and started sucking hard on Dec 5th 2020 or somewhere around that time frame. Anyway, that is my experience. Still going to try a few things. I'll post if I make progress.

review_title: Streaming Stick + Eats Remote Batteries in a Week if Unplugged
review_text: I have one of these Streaming Stick + that works. It’s stays “on” all the time; it is powered on all the time.I bought a second one and the tv powers the USB port off when it turns off.The batteries die in the remote in about 5-6 days. I have been through 5 or 6 pairs of batteries in a couple of months. It’s awful.Roku support is unhelpful. They followed up twice with a long questionnaire about the issue but they don’t follow up any more after this, and I answered their questions in detail.I have had made 4 attempts through chat and email to resolve the issue, and have now given up. And I never leave bad reviews. Others should be warned about this situation, though.Roku told me to keep the device plugged in, basically, and never responded again even though I have reached out three more times.IMHO they don’t have an answer and blew me off.The issue is documented on a Reddit thread I found so there are others with this issue even though Roku denies it.I believe other units will work in this situation (needing the roku to be powered off when not in use), so you can get other Rokus. Skip the streaming Stick + with the voice remote. It’s not good unless you want to use your phone as a remote or love buying or recharging batteries every week!

review_title: Problem With Device and Poor Customer Support; Roku Does Not Horror Their Warranty
review_text: I have owned several Roku streaming devices during the past and have never had any issues with the devices. However, the Streaming Stick+ is a different story. Very often, the stick freezes up and is totally unresponsive. The only way I have found to get it working again is to unplug it and wait 60 seconds. I contacted customer support via Chat and the representative was of no help. He told me he would send troubleshooting steps to correct the problem via my email but I never received them. I then called customer service's phone number and waited almost an hour but was never able to speak with a representative. I was unable to find any troubleshooting solutions to this problem on line. If this is the best Roku can do, I'm switching to Fire Stick.Update: After communicating with Roku's Technical Support via emails for two weeks, I still have not resolved the problem with my Streaming Stick+. It still freezes up several times a day and I have to unplug it for 60 seconds and then restore power to reboot. Even then, it does not always work and I must reboot several more times to get it going again. Customer Service is TERRIBLE. It appears that the Tech may be overseas and using a language program to translate based on the tech's poor grammar and misspelled words. Also, you can forget about the one year warranty! They are quick to blame the problem on everything except their device and will not consider replacing the device. My advice is to avoid purchasing the Roku Streaming Stick+.

review_text: I think the ROKU system is awesome, but the Streaming Sticks interface to the remote control is horrible with useless voice command capability. I have had the Streaming stick for almost a year. When the remote works it is good, but that is rare. The original remote control started going bad after about 4 months. I asked ROKU to send me another one and they did. And it is going bad also, or I thought. And then I looked up REMOTE CONTROL ISSUES on Streaming Stick and found there was an extender HDMI cable they will send you for free to fix the remote response lagging issues supposedly caused by the Streaming stick being plugged directly into your HDMI port. I though awesome, maybe now I won't have to wait up to 5 minutes for the remote control to respond to a button push. The cable came after about 4 or 5 days, and I tried it right away. IT MADE IT WORSE!!!!!. I gave it three days and it did not get better. Worst remote control I have ever had on any TV. And I am 60 and have used countless TV's and remote controls. I had to start using the ROKU remote control app on my Samsung Smart Phone. Response is great on the app, but a remote without buttons that you have to look at every time you want to change the Channel or fast forward past commercials sucks. SO.... I am sending it back before my year warranty is up. I am going to try the top of the line Roku ULTRA. If that doesn't work, I think I will be going back to Dish Network. Best remote I have ever used on the Dish system.

review_title: A Great Device Unless You Need Help
review_text: 3rd Roku, so I thought I knew what I was doing. This particular one comes with NO instructions whatsoever. At first, it seemed fine, though a picture of the connections is critical for new users. But this one only let me set up the network and then thought it was done, giving me some weird options. I dug deeper and found another user name associated with my device. I knew this was wrong. If anything weird happens to you (and this is NOT documented on Roku's site), go to the device attached to your HDMI port. Using a flashlight, you'll find an almost invisible button. Push and hold for 10 sec. This is a factory reset. When you do this, it should walk you neatly thru the setup process and all will be good. But how would you know? This should be a. part of the package insert - basic instructions are key. and b. on the website. I went everywhere trying to find an answer and finally did a chat. It took quite a while as the people answering appear to think you had info and that you understand their poorly worded advice. Once setup, it is a great little thing and much better than any Roku that has a separate little box. That one was always a problem for me. Stick with the streaming stick.

This went on for days while the Roku team sent me condescending emails with long lists of what I had to do to make their unreliable hardware work. I eventually solved the problem by ignoring it and trying again seven days later without doing any of the things on their long list. As I relaxed with Netflix, the Roku CS team kept sending me emails and finally called me. Do any of you answer calls from unknown numbers? Not enough time in the day. More email tag ensued, during which time the Roku stick again malfunctioned. Out of the blue - no one bumped into the TV stand or jostled the stick. There were no electrical surges or WIFI problems. Just cut out in the middle of a movie. Bad engineering or poor quality control, take your pick. Do they think this will motivate me to update my TV? Certainly not with one of theirs.

review_title: Flexible and easy to use streaming device. Highly recommend.
review_text: Very impressed with these. We now have them on four televisions at home. Good choice of streaming providers (many free) and very flexible. If you do subscribe to a paid service through the Roku device, the billing is handled correctly. If you are already subscribed directly with a paid service, the authentication by Roku works correctly. Search feature seems to work well across multiple channels. We have not used the voice recognition feature. The Roku remotes have paired well with three different brands of television (on/off, volume, etc.) and are easy to use. Reliable WIFI connections are maintained. While all our televisions are "smart", the Roku wireless connection seems to have less latency issues than some televisions, and Roku has a wider choice of services than some smart tvs. We have found it very helpful to have the single Roku menu and command scheme on all our televisions. This results in way fewer clicks to get where you want to go and less confusion when you sit down in front of different televisions. (The television remote overrides the Roku, so it's east to switch back and forth if you need to.) The only small downside we have noted is that the Roku remotes seem to eat batteries more quickly than other devices. Overall a slick and reliable tool.

review_text: I'm a pretty tech-savvy cord-cutter and until very recently I was using my laptop with an HDMI cable as my streaming device. I got tired of this cobbled-together solution and decided to try a streaming device. I looked into Chromecast and Fire Stick before purchasing this Roku. I really wanted to like the Chromecast with Google TV because I am already very Google-centric, but the combination of price, the rich selection of apps, and the streamlined interface sold me. I rarely use voice commands in the home because it disturbs family members, and I also don't use a smart home device such as Alexa or Google Nest.My only real CON is a large one: I really hate the remote, and having a dedicated remote was one of the reasons I was getting sick of using my laptop. First off, NO BACKLIGHT. Why this feature isn't standard on remote controls these days is beyond me. If there was a backlight, I wouldn't have nearly as big a problem with the key and button layout. Every TV and cable remote control I've ever owned (and I'm 57 years old) has had a (more or less) standard layout, and I've NEVER had a remote with volume buttons on the side. That is a phone feature! And the four favorite buttons for Netflix, Disney+, hulu and sling are at the very bottom, where I expect to find navigation such as play and pause. So I'm constantly trying to pause a video and instead launching one of these four premium services, of which I subscribe to NONE. (Why isn't one of them Amazon Prime Video? And why can't I customize them?) And none of this would bother me nearly as much if there wasn't a BLANK SPACE 1-1/4" square UNDER the four favorites buttons.So I would take the middle tier of buttons and move them to below the favorites, and put the volume and mute buttons where they belong - in the middle of the remove.OK I'm done. Thanks for reading!

review_title: Mighty convenient, missing important power-user features.
review_text: I have very high expectations for my audio/video gear. When streaming audio or video, I am used to using a home theater PC connected to my TV via a receiver. This is fantastic for most things, but it isn't very convenient or easy to use. Additionally and unfortunately, many streaming apps for Windows don't support the highest level of audio or video quality, which is very frustrating.To solve the convenience, ease of use, and quality problems, I purchased one of these. And the Roku Streaming Stick+ is very convenient (small, easy WiFi connectivity), easy to use (great interface), and allows me to stream high quality from apps like Netflix and Disney+.However, there are a few major problems with this piece of gear:1. Ads. I hate that there are ads littered about the Roku interface. Come on.2. No advanced features such as A/V sync offset. For some reason, audio in certain Roku apps is out of sync from the video. Neither my receiver nor my TV have options for modifying this sync - usually, I just change that setting per-application on my HTPC, and I'm happy. But there exists no such setting on Roku, which makes certain content unwatchable.3. The first copy of this piece of hardware I got from Amazon was dead on arrival and wouldn't turn on. I returned that Stick and purchased a replacement.

review_text: After having Directv satellite for 18 years at my house (which I loved despite the breaks during storms), I called customer service because monthly price has gone from $92 to $163 in the past year, but they refused to discount any further so time to say goodbye to Directv. After some research I decided on Youtube TV. Next it was looking for a streaming device. I am a channel surfer so quickness navigating between apps and programs to stream was of high importance. I have an Asus RT-N66U router and Spectrum 100MB cable internet so bandwidth shouldn't limit me. I first tried the streaming Stick + from Roku which gets glowing reviews. I connected it via my 5G wireless (in the next room about 8' away from the TV) and it was very sluggish and reported a slow internet connection. Doing a connection test in the ROKU reported 1Mb/s though the laptop on speedtest on the same wireless reported 54Mb/s. I've had spotty coverage in the house with the 5G wireless so I switched to the slower and Roku was then happy with the porformance showing nearly what the laptop did.Pros - I like the Roku menus, DVR setup, layout, and the simple remote... Using a Panasonic Plasma 1080P, the picture is excellent with absolutely no complaints. I didn't test anything with soundCons - What I don't like is the latency when switching among apps or when kicking off a stream. Seems to buffer for about 8-10 seconds before the program starts playing. I'm guessing this is buffering because if I compare what is streaming for a local channel to antenna input on the TV for the same channel, the Roku was about 8-10 seconds behind. I have Youtube TV, Amazon Prime Video, and Netflix with the slowness the worst with Youtube TV. I also don't like that you can't set a particular app to automatically run on startup.At less than one third the cost of Directv, I'll stick with it but it feels like going backwards in performance... like if you had to get rid of the SSD in your Core-I7 laptop for a slow hard drive.Note that I moved the streaming stick + to the bedroom TV and got a Roku Ultra for the main TV. This time connected to ethernet and Roku reporting 78 Mb/s or better. While the performance is slightly better, it still doesn't have the quickness I'd like. I'll keep watching reviews for something better...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2019
author: R. Perry

review_title: Sooooo disappointed from a long time Roku customer
review_text: I strongly advise against buying this streaming stick. I replaced my older Roku stick with this SS+ thinking it will be faster while also having a stronger Wifi antenna. When I first installed it I was not disappointed. It worked great...for about 2 weeks. Out of nowhere it would not play a single video from any streaming service, displaying a "HDCP error" and advising me to unplug it and plug it back in. Well that didn't work. I did a 'system reset'. Nope. I changed the display type and dropped the resolution down to 780p. Nope. It even said HDCP compliant on the display type! I went to the Roku forum and saw hundreds of other customers having the exact same problem - it worked for a while and then suddenly the HDCP error out of nowhere. Some said it would go away for a while and then come back intermittently. For many others like myself nothing worked. I sense there is a firmware issue that Roku refuses to acknowledge. Customers called into Roku only to be disconnected. They said the customer service was horrible. I'm returning it and buying the Amazon Stick. Until Roku admits and addresses the problem I am done with them. This is a big black eye for Roku.

review_title: my journey to 4k hdr 60hz with a sony tv, yamaha surround sound receiver and this roku stick
review_text: Ok. This is going to be long…but maybe something through my experience will help you solve something faster than me.I ended up with the Sony x800g 75” led 4k UHD HDR10 tv.Lots of numbers there. And often times you will hear stuff used interchangeably.• 4k isn’t all the same. So the term 4k related to the number of pixels on your screen.o 1080p was previous HD (high definition) and was 1920x1080 pixels.o 4k is generally 3840x2160• UHD is ultra high definition which also refers to the resolution of 3840x2160, however there are two versions of this.o One is 30hz. Normal movies and tv look “normal”o 60hz is great for action movies and fast movement such as sports• HDR/HDR10 also has two versions, but in simple terms, HDR is used to describe a certain grouping of picture settings to make your 4k look better. Higher contrast rates(darker black and whiter white). However there are 2 versions of this alsoo 30hz for traditional movies and tvo 60hz is great for those action movies and sports.What happened for me. It was time for a new tv. I already had a Yamaha surround sound receiver that all my consoles, and fire/roku sticks, and blueray players plugged into, and one single cable going to my tv. So the setup of a new tv was going to be fairly painless. Find the tv, buy the tv, remove the old tv and replace it with the new one. I got home, got the new one in place and hooked up with one hdmi connection…and it didn’t do 4k. WTF! So I did some research and realized the roku stick that we use for amazon prime, hulu, and Netflix…wasn’t 4k compatible. So I went online, ordered a Roku Premier. I got it the next day, thanks amazon. Hooked it up, and it worked well…but the remote had to be line of site with the roku box. Unfortunately, my home theater setup made this a huge pain in the butt because the roku was hidden behind the Yamaha surround sound receiver. So, I returned this and ordered the Roku Streaming Stick +. Because these are meant to plug in behind the tv or to a surround sound receiver. This in place, and I ran the setup on the roku stick for display and it would do 4k uhd but only in 30hz. Fearing I had bought the wrong one. I took it upstairs to my lg 40” tv and plugged it in, turned on the tv. And the tv recognized the roku stick and I saw the screen go from normal black screen (kinda dark grey really) to true solid black with the HDR logo flashing on screen. When it showed the roku menu, I ran the same display setup and it clicked green check marks next to 4k uhd 30hz, 4k uhd 60hz, 4k hdr 30hz, and 4k hdr 60hz. And the movies (6 underground on Netflix) was just a freaking work of art. So now I knew that it was not the roku stick. So doing more research I found out that my Yamaha rx-v685 surround sound receiver would accept this beautiful signal and would pass through 4k but that the configuration had to be adjusted to do this. So I dug around in the menu, found the setting and clicked it into 4k. It looked okay on the new screen, but didn’t look amazing. So I went back to the google, and found out that my receiver would pass through only 4k uhd 30hz. So…it would look okay. But wouldn’t be jaw dropping. Did some research and found that I needed to buy the newer version of the receiver the RX-v683BL, that was $400 on ebay for a new in box one. It showed up a week later in a damaged box, but was fine cosmetically and functionally. I installed this new receiver with all the same connections and such. And ran the same roku display test, got it to do 4k uhd 30hz, and 4k uhd 60hz but it wouldn’t do 4k hdr 30 or 60. Annoyed at this point, I started scouring everything I could, and started seeing that folks said they solved this problem with better cables. I figured why not. So I found a set that had great reviews on amazon (info below) and those showed up two days later. I ran one of these from the new Yamaha receiver to the tv. Because the roku stick plugged in directly to a port on the back of the tv. Ran the test and got the 4k uhd’s working but only the 4k hdr 30hz working. I wanted the last step because I wanted the 4k resolution with the hdr picture quality with the 60 hz for high speed smooth movements. Annoyed again, I found that the tv instead of using HDMI port 1, needed to have me use HDMI port 2 or 3. I tried that, same. Then I went into the menu for the tv and found that there was a picture setting under settings>watch tv>external inputs>hdmi signal format>select the port 2 I was plugged into now and change it from standard to enhanced 4:4:4 or 4:2:2 mode. Tried again, the image was looking better but the roku still wouldn’t let me have the 4k hdr 60hz. So I checked the Yamaha receiver and the HDMI mode had to be in mode 1 as well as the roku stick had to be in ports 1-5. I ran the test again…still no luck. A final run at google and someone said there was a buried adjustment within the settings>advanced system settings>HDMI output and it also had to be set to the 4:4:4 or 4:2:2. Ran the settings and success! So when I boil it all down, when hooking something up to a 4k UHD HDR10(60hz) tv you need to have the correct device, the correct settings on the device, the right cable, the right port plugged in for the device, and also have the settings enabled for that device. I know that was long winded, but I figure I’ll use this story in the amazon review and maybe it helps someone sometime.

review_text: Overall I'm pleased with roku stuff. The streaming quality is good, they do what they're intended to do, mostly. There is definitely a compromise between this and the ultra. It's just a lot more sluggish to operate. But my main point of this review is to make a point. I upgraded our stuff because these held the promise of private listening. A feature that's just crucial to a parent who is tired of watching stuff at minimal volume because someone is sleeping or there's language. Sadly that's the main reason I'm disappointed. Private listening, which allows you to watch on your TV, while using the remote app on your phone to stream audio to your headphones. It's a really awesome thing to have, and generally sounds great. But... It just fails to deliver. It does deliver constant audio cut out. Sometimes you lose every other sentence being said. I have to use subtitles just to keep up and I often still have to hit the replay button. I have used 4 different streaming stick+s in three different houses (and three different network setups), and with different phones and headphones combinations. It's their service, plain and simple. And this doesn't have the controller headphone jack so that's not an option. So if you're just using this on a TV to play stuff and have no interest in listening with headphones, then this is a good product. But if you plan on that being a big part of your usage, look elsewhere.
