review_text: Solution/Work around.I have a ROKU Stick+ on an LG 49UH6030. The LG software 05.30.90 is up to date.This LG TV does not handle Amazon Prime HDR properly. The images are way too dark and no settings tweaking makes them acceptable. The LG TV displays Disney+ and Apple TV HDR content just fine, so the problem is probably with the Prime Video app.This problem is apparent on Prime Video via HDMI as well as on the Prime Video app installed on the LG OS. My specific test video is the Amazon-produced Chi-Raq by Spike Lee. I used a DVD of the same content on my upscaling Sony BD player as a control and the DVD disc displayed properly and far better than the 4K HDR streaming on this TV.ROKU reports that the LG TV HDMI port is 4K, HDR, 60 Hz, HDCP 2.2 via the auto-detect in ROKU/Settings/Display_Type.My solution is to choose the 4K, 60 Hz setting without HDR. Now 4K videos that were detected by the TV as having HDR play properly. The LG TV has HDR-effect display settings for non-HDR items to compensate.This LG-TV/Prime Video HDR issue does not appear to be exclusive to the ROKU Stick+ but ROKU's settings flexibility provided the work around that was needed for this TV.

review_title: Won't control separate audio system - check TV audio pass through compatibility before you buy!
review_text: So I have a 5 year old LG TV and a separate sound system. The TV does not control sound through the optical port out for my sound system (just outputs max line level volume always then set my amplifier to a reasonable level). Currently I have a mini computer, which I can control the sound through my wireless keyboard. Therefore the Roku, while it controls the TV sound is unable to control the output to my sound system. Called tech support and they said my TV is too old, although it's not that old... Don't see why the roku can't just control the sound out from the HDMI like a computer can, maybe it takes too much extra electronics. Also, I can't buy a receiver with IR and control it from the remote either because it's only programmed with TV IR codes for some reason (it specifically says cannot control AVR in setup...), seems like another thing they could have added... Either way it doesn't work so I'll either return it or get a pass through line level volume controller with it's own remote, not ideal but it might work.

review_text: I purchased this item about 18 months ago but didn't take it out of the box until two weeks ago. The four one-click buttons on the remote for Netflix, etc. can't be re-programmed. While the Netflix button is great since I have that service, the other 3 are useless. It would have been great to be able to reprogram them to work with an app of my choice.2. The power and volume controls do NOT work with an AV receiver, only a TV. Since I have the stick plugged into my receiver, neither button is functional. Disappointing.I also have a Fire TV box attached to the system. In comparison, the Roku menus are pretty dated looking as is the overall navigation. The remote is more clunky and doesn't respond as quickly at times. But, the Roku has apps that the Fire TV does not, so having both gives me more choices.

review_title: Works great when it works. The remote was faulty and Roku Customer Service is horrible
review_text: I've previously purchased and installed about 7 of these streaming stick +s, all without a problem. I purchased this one in January for my home, and the remote didn't work out of the box. I did all the troubleshooting, replaced batteries with new (which it drained in one day), searched Roku community boards, and it was clear this is a faulty remote. (I used the iPhone Roku app to control the stick and that worked perfectly, so we know it was the remote itself.) I reported all of this on the community boards with no reply from Roku. I tried customer service. No phone number was available to call, and email correspondence was broken, so I used the chat feature. I spent about 40 minutes on the chat explaining all the troubleshooting I did, providing serial and model numbers, etc, etc. I just asked for them to replace the remote, not the entire device. Well, as of today, they have yet to respond with any resolution (the device was purchased in early January, it's a month later as of this writing). By the way, did I mention that according to the Roku community, this is a known issue?I returned the entire device to Amazon, after speaking to Amazon customer service, and they supported that return. I purchased a new one (for $10 less!) but when it arrived, the box had already been torn open, so given my recent experience, I returned it to Amazon the same day.I know everything is crazy regarding the pandemic, but this was a simple issue they could have easily resolved and kept a happy customer. I may purchase an Apple TV instead (yes, it's more expensive, but I have an older one and it works great--and Apple customer service is excellent) Not sure what I'm going to do with the others, but if they begin to have issues, they may be going back as well. review_title: 1 yr Review Update: Constant wifi drops, display problems and technical issues abound. Do not buy.
review_text: 1 year review update:Boy was I wrong about Roku being a solution. After a year now I can say with certainty that rokus own technology - hardware and especially software - are the very things youll be fighting with daily. This is horrible tech and theres no solutions here, just more problems than youve already got.Frequently dropping wifi, constant HDCP issues and settings that keep "forgetting" themselves, crashes all the time and all manner of streaming issues. Sometimes the picture is so pixelated I cant make it out, like it's a dying VCR tape or something - and Ive got 60M meg downstream cable internet service. Roku is the only platform that makes netlfix, hulu and sometimes Youtube an absolute chore to watch in comfort.My roku 4k plus Roku Streaming stick is garbage and a waste of time. I want to burn it, like in a fire. Thats how unhappy I am with Roku.Old review:Roku does a good job, and it kinda the Peacemaker of streaming platforms. Ok, yes the User Interface sucks and is pretty non-uniform/inconsistent in design, but the technology is GREAT and most importantly Roku is the only neutral ground for TV cable-cutter streaming services. Playstation has Vue so theyll never allow DirectTV Now or Sling or YouTube TV apps on PS4/PS5 etc, Amazon has their streaming services so they also ban certain direct competitors apps, same with Google TV devices and Apple TV etc...Most hardware manufacturers also have their own competing streaming services or have exclusive deals with one of them, and so they actively prevent and ban any competition from their platform, forcing the customer to use the one available option. Roku is like Switzerland - independent and neutral, without a directly competing service... And so EVERYONE makes a Roku app, and in that sense Roku is a fair free-trade zone, where quality and value of a given service is the only way to beat a competiting app... Roku is a neutral space where all the dirty tricks various companies use to force you to exist solely within their own software ecosystem don't have any reach. A pure free market, allowing the customer to win no matter how cutthroat the varied service providers want to be. Roku is the sherrif that keep Corporate greed at bay in a way. Worth dealing with the frustratingly poor UI design.

review_title: How To Fix Issues with 4k HDR Samsung TVs
review_text: We've loved Roku for a long time. This year we decided to upgrade our TV to a 4k HDR Samsung. To provide the streaming services, we got this Roku Streaming Stick +. Unfortunately, the picture quality through the Roku was terrible - washed out colors, contrast too high, everything too dark, and lost clarity. This was universal, but especially bad in some Disney Plus titles like the Mandalorian, which was unwatchable.I still had the old LED TV with a Roku 3, and I compared them side by side. The old setup looked perfect. So I plugged in my Roku 3 to the new TV - and the issues all disappeared. It was crisp, bright, and colorful. So the issues were with the new Roku Streaming Stick+.To make a long story short, after much experimentation and research, I was able to get the new Roku to look as good as the old. Here's how you do it:• Go to Settings > Display type and set it to just 4k - WITHOUT the HDR. It turns out that there are some issues with Samsung TV's HDR settings and 4k Rokus. Upon changing this setting, I found my picture through the new Roku Streaming Stick+ was once again clear and bright.• The other issue was all the "smart" features on the Samsung were messing things up. Turning them all off and setting the TV to "Game mode: On" for the Roku brought back the intended brightness, contrast, and color range.As an aside, when these issues appeared, I also bought a Chromecast with Google TV. It had the same issues as the new Roku, but did NOT have the ability to turn off HDR, so it wasn't able to solve all the display issues like the Roku.I hope this helps someone!

review_title: Better than some things, but the ad buttons irritate me
review_text: I got this because even though my TV has built-in Netflix and some other things, it doesn't have YouTube or Funimation, so I had been using the PS4 apps for those, and they're not good. The Roku version of the Funimation app is much better. If you only need the biggest streaming services (Netflix, Amazon Prime, etc.) then most TVs seem to come with those already these days. But Roku is pretty good for smaller channels.My main gripe is the fact that they sell positions on the quick buttons to various companies/channels, and you as the consumer have zero control over which buttons you get. Mine came with Disney Plus, Netflix, Sling, and Hulu. If you don't actually use the apps on the buttons, those buttons are just wasted and annoying. You can't even see which buttons any individual remote will have when you buy it (they rotate, but it's pure chance what you'll get). I just really hate buying a product and then having part of *my* possession sold as ad space for a company I may or may not want to support or have any interest in. Roku offers a version that has programmable buttons--but it's the most expensive version, it's only two buttons, and those are *in addition to* the four buttons that they sell as ad space. I wish Roku would focus more on their customers than their vendors/business partners and instead put the ad buttons only on the very cheapest model or as a cheaper version of each model (so you get a discount for agreeing to see the ads) and just make all four buttons programmable by the user as the default.

review_title: A cheaper, equally clever alternative to Apple TV. Its flaws are less severe than Apple TV's.
review_text: 1) The streaming seems flawless on this device - and on the "ultra", which I purchased first.2) There is a dizzying number of channels, and except for the movies at the apple store, you essentially get all the channels found on apple.3) Subscription for YouTube TV is $50 when you use the YouTube TV app in Roku. I'm told it is $55.00 if you subscribe to YouTube TV on Apple TV; you pay Apple $60.00 extra bucks per year - the price of a good Roku device.4) However, some areas are significantly less developed than others. It has excellent connectivity, and streaming, programming are great. But even though it’s been around for many years, it has some frustrating interface problems.a) You cannot setup any of the device parameter from your computer. On the other hand, Apps and individual channels allow you to setup setup online, and the settings are preserved from one Roku device to the other. An example is YouTube TV and PBS.b) On your computer, you can select Roku channels/apps and your work will apply to to all the devices. But you cannot setup any particular sequencing for the icons. You can sequence them on a device, but Roku doesn't let you share that sequencing on other devices. For example, if you want YouTube TV at the top, followed by Netflix, you must separately rearrange the icons on each device.c) The buttons on the remote are not programmable. If you don't want a subscription to Netflix, why should a button devoted to Netflix be in your face all the time? why should you be subjected to the risk of pressing the button in the dark? Roku's solution to accidental button presses is to ask: "are you sure you want to exit whatever you're watching?" - but this addresses a totally different problem. THERE SHOULD BE A WAY TO DEFEAT THESE BUTTONS OR TO PROGRAM THEM AS YOU WISH. Netflix pays money to Roku for this, but Roku subjects the customers to frustration, as they are likely to press the button my mistake and then have to go through several steps in order to get out of, for example, Netflix.Still and all, I think Roku is every bit as good as Apple TV. Roku's most expensive device, during discounts times, is less than half the price of Apple TV.

review_title: I love Roku, but the remote will NOT stay paired!
review_text: I ordered my first Roku in 2012. It was an LT. it has been great! When we upgraded to a 4K tv, I wanted to get a 4K streaming device, so I ordered this. The picture is really awesome and we have not had buffering issues, like we had started having with our LT. It was nice at first to not have to point the remote at an IR device. Despite all the channels and niceties of the device, two things were annoying. Only one of this things so bad that it absolutely won’t work for us. First, the addition of amazon ads was a surprise and a TRULY annoying one, as now we need to have our children cover eyes and mute the tv during ads. review_text: I purchased the Roku Streaming Stick + a few months back but have been having persistent HDCP Errors. The Error would happen every few minutes and was extremely annoying. I really wanted this $56 device to work so I researched several solutions and found this one on some geek page. I don’t know what that says about me but, long story short here’s what you can do if returning your Roku Streaming Stick + is no longer an option and you have an extra $40 to spend.In able to use a HDMI cable that is HDCP 2.2 compliant as the Error page indicates, you must first plug your ROKU SS+ into the input of a HDCP 2.2 compliant HDMI splitter, then connect your 2.2 compliant cable to one of the outputs on the splitter to a HDMI input on your TV. Since the Roku SS+ derives it’s power through a very short usb cable, I simply kept the splitter/Stick union close to the USB port on the back of the TV to allow use of the provided cable front the Roku SS+ to the usb port. I happened to already have a 3D brand splitter that worked just fine but I suspect others will work as well as long as they are HDCP 2.2 compliant.I’ve included some pics. Note you can see both ends of my new, black colored HDMI cable running from the splitter output to the HDMI input on the TV (the HDMI input on my tv is sort of hidden behind the Roku in the picture) and the short usb cable running from the Roku SS+ to the USB port on my LG tv for power. The splitter has a stand alone power source but when I plugged the USB powered Roku into the splitter it provided power to both the splitter and the Roku and I did not need to use it. Hope this helps!Two days since I added the splitter to my cable arrangement and so far no more HDCP Errors! The picture and sound is fantastic. Finally working like it should have on its own. Would have gotten 5 stars if it had!

review_text: *Long Range WIFI, works in "dead wifi zones"*Boosts the internet and no lag*Easy setup*Wonderful ROKU app (you can listen to your shows on your phone/bluetooth listening devices)*Connects to Alexa*Streaming option "share screen"-compatible with iPhones and Androids*Roku remote can control the TV (on/off & volume)*Roku remote has voice controlIt picks up the internet and the play back is always on point. review_title: Works well, customer support is legit
review_text: I'm posting this review mostly to document my experience with Roku support. I have three of these in my home, and am pretty happy with how they work. Recently, one of them "bricked", not sure if it was due to an update or just hardware failure (after about 7 months of use). Went on Roku and did chat-based support. It took about 30 minutes to walk through the hard reset, restart, etc. steps with the rep that I had already done. When we got to the end of the process, the rep sent me an RMA number and address to mail my Roku stick to. A week, later, I got a replacement. Bottom line, the company stand behind its product.The product hasn't really changed, although I did notice that the remote now has a "non-slip" type finish as opposed to the slick glossy finish my previous remotes had (which is a little nicer). Yet to be determined if the remote eats batteries as quickly as the old one.Other than the remote's battery consumption, my only complaint as a multiple device owner has to do with setup. When activating the Roku, I have to go through the whole "channel selection" setup again, which is kind of annoying. My devices are registered with Roku, and they should know what I use. It's also painful to have to re-register each channel (Hulu, Netflix, etc.) but I'm guessing that is because of "differences of opinion" in how registration should work (i.e. does Hulu trust Roku to act as an authentication proxy).

review_text: Somehow, a company called Caligeeks hijacked my Roku. On 2/8/2020 during the setup of this Roku the screen wouldn't allow me to continue setup unless I called the listed phone # on screen. They made me believe I couldn't work my Roku without them and that all Roku customers would have to pay this fee each time they bought a Roku. I don't know how their phone # appeared on my Roku, but I argued with them for an hour (since I already had a Roku and knew it was free to set up an account). They had thick accents and were hard to understand on top of it.If Roku is going through a 3rd party for weekend support, there should be information about it upfront instead of lying to customers telling them it's MANDATORY. It's not mandatory. It left a bad taste in my mouth for Roku.Also, the Roku remote was faulty. I messed with it forever and followed all the troubleshooting multiple times and it still didn't work. review_title: Excellent value. Some questions answered here if you're interested.
review_text: After a few months of using the cheaper basic Roku, I decided to upgrade to the Streaming Stick+, though I couldn't seem to get answers to some tech questions here or on their website.The video is wonderfully clear when streaming from my desktop computer or when streaming from the Xfinity streaming service - or through the Roku channel for that matter. I think some serious upscaling is going on. The sound is amazing streaming from my computer, but be aware that most streaming services don't broadcast in surround sound - you'll have to settle for stereo until they decide there's enough demand for it.Set up was mostly easy, except that in my case, there was some sort of glitch that caused streaming errors at first. The solution was simple: go into settings and find the "restart" option, and then re-install the services you subscribe to.If you rip your own video, you'll find that the Stick won't render vobsubs or PGS subs at all. Those are the subs that come with DVDs and BluRay disks. But you can easily download srt subs from various websites. Streamed movies and TV shows do, of course, have subs that work. The subs are displayed in compact form with a black background for easy reading without getting in the way of opening credits.And here's the question nobody could answer for me: The stick WILL handle the x265 HEVC codec. This is a real advantage if you rip your own video from your disks. HEVC will pack some great clarity into much smaller files.One thing I don't like, is the menu navigation in the media app (where it streams from your computer in the other room). When you go into a folder, and then come back out, the other folders are sometimes not displayed. The solution is to go "home" and then enter the app again. Then you can select from all the content. The same bug was in the cheap Roku, so I think they don't know about it.Given the price, this is a compact workhorse that will deliver your entertainment reliably in hi-def. Pretty much anything I watch from now on will come through this little stick, except for when I play a physical disk.

review_text: I like this 2019 Roku Stick + better than the previous (2017) version primarily because it puts off less heat. The previous stick version would physically get very hot. Then intermittently a warning would come up on the screen that it was overheating.To resolve that, the power had to be cut to let it cool down. I purchased a USB hub with power buttons to do that daily. So far the new version has not felt as hot to the touch nor has a warning popped up.The new version also has a small box integrated into the USB power cord. This may be the resolution for the heat problem.Other than that, this new version also has includes a mute button on the remote. It is supposed to have a quad core processor. I have not noticed any significant speed increase how it operates. I will say that the sticks have 802.11ac network capability that makes them run better than the Roku Express. which only has up to 802.11n network speed.As for voice recognition, that does not work as well as I would hope. Many times it does not recognize what I am saying. So I don’t use it.I purchased many of these for home and as gifts as they were on sale in December for $29 each, which was a good deal. I have had good feedback from others that it works well.I recommend the Roku Stick + of you want a fast, cooler streaming channel device.By the way, as of this time, the CBS Roku app will not allow use without a CBS ALL ACCESS subscription. The smart phone app does allow broadcast show access at no extra cost, which can be streamed to a Google Chromecast device, not to Roku. That is CBS’ choice.

review_title: The REMOTES are JUNK in less than one year!?!?!
review_text: Update on 7/25/2020:2 Remotes have quit working within 8 months of my purchase. I have replaced batteries, tried to resync and nothing solves the issue. We now have to use my cell phone and Roku app in 2 different rooms of our home just to use the streaming sticks which are our only source of TV news and movies. I purchased 2 replacement devices about one month thinking I was giving us backup devices and now I am past their return window and I know those remotes are going to crap out on me too...NOT HAPPY with dropping a total of $250+ when the remotes last less than 1 year.Update on 01/07/2020:We now have three if these because our Daughter’s “smart” TV that is just over a year old suddenly decided to have issues with all of the built in apps. This stick is perfect for those who have this happen, or have a TV without built in apps, or those like me who used their game system for streaming until too much use fried an expensive console and caused the loss of hundreds and hundreds of hours of save game data! I recommend these to everyone because they are perfect for our streaming only household.Orig Review:Okay...I absolutely fried my PS4 because as much as I would use it to game on I would also use it to fire up my Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu, etc. I never checked into these types of devices before because I guess I just thought my PS4 would be eternal (LOL). As all things tech related eventually do, my PS4 completely crashed and hundreds of hours on my games were lost to me, but in that awful sad moment I decided to replace my PS4 AND go ahead and buy 2 of these to use here at home so that our XBox One wouldn't suffer the same fate in our living room. I know...I'm terrible, huh?Anyways - ROKU. LOVE IT, LOVE IT, LOVE IT! So easy to setup, easy to add apps to your menu, easy to navigate, quick to load the apps and most important of all I no longer have to worry about using my gaming consoles as entertainment beyond the games they are meant to play! Win Win!!!!I am seriously amazed at how quick the apps launch/load - it's darn near immediate and the interface is clean and easy to use. I love that I can add apps/manage everything from anywhere even when I'm not at home - adding and removing channels is a breeze. It even recognized our TVs without any issues and even some of the universal TV remotes we've bought cannot do that as efficiently as the ROKU did. We are definitely going to be long-time ROKU fans and will buy new ones when needed because they are well worth the price. My husband loves the one in the living room and he has never watched as much TV as he has since I installed the ROKU out there. If we had more TVs we would have more ROKU's.

review_text: Late last year I broke my 1080p tv. Luckily was able to get a brand new 4k tv a few months later. At first I thought since it was a 4k smart tv I could watch 4k movies. Man was I wrong. Learned only select devices can no matter the tv. So I knew it was time for a new Roku player (had a gen 1 so didn't look good even on 4k). After shopping around and asking questions I went with the Roku streaming stick+. I love it. It even makes non 4k movies and shows look amazing. For the price its so worth it. I was nervous at first because I read my 4k tv needed hdcp 2.2 hdmi outlets or else at best would be 1080p and I couldn't find anything in the manual and behind the tv to say it did. But found out through research my tv did.What is also nice is the fact its not a box, its a stick that goes into a hdmi port (rather then hdmi cable connecting the two) so less clutter on the shelf. Also you don't need to aim the remote directly at it to use it. You can be in front of a wall and it would work. So no need to worry about where you stick it in the tv (for me the hdmis were behind the tv and not on the side). It is your typical Roku player, has the same apps as the first gen plus any 4k apps (there is a section for it). Also some of the apps (Netflix, hulu) looks completely different then their older model counterparts so had to get used to it.The remote is your standard Roku. Same set up with some very nice features. If you sync it to your tv you can turn off the tv without tv remote and even control the volume (volume controls are on the side) so makes it easier versus using two remotes. A very nice feature is audio control. Kind of like siri or alexxa.. You push the button and make a command to open an app or search for a movie, show or app.Overall the pros are great and cons are nothing to worry about. Id do some research before buying to make sure your tv has the right hdmi ports or else you spent more money on the same thing as a cheap model for non 4k tvs. Defiantly recommend.Pros:-amazing picture for both 4k and hd-No box-don't need to aim remote at device-price-remote features-voice controlCons:-needs a specific hdmi for it to work-some apps are different then the ones on other Roku models

review_title: Best Collection of streamings Apps for the buck, Lousy Internet connection
review_text: For the money, Roku has the greatest palette of apps - HBOMax, Apple TV and so many more. However, they appear to have equipped this Streaming Stick+ with the cheapest, weakest WiFi receiver possible. We have high-speed Spectrum cable internet, and our router is right in the living room with our TV, about 12 feet away. All our devices (computer, iPad, phones, etc.) show full bars anywhere in that room, and the LG OLED TV itself has no trouble getting a strong signal on any other app - Netflix, Prime Video, etc.Yet the Roku stick, plugged into the HDMI port on the side of the TV, showed a weak connection of only 3 out of 5 bars, and buffered miserably upon watching. Moving the router within 5’ got us up to 4 bars and less connection glitches. Getting up to a strong 5-bar signal required moving our router RIGHT NEXT TO the TV.Unacceptable, period, for a 2021 WiFi-dependent streaming device...so cannot recommend.

Of course I only have a few of them actually downloaded but the flexibility of choice is a huge plus. The one area that I feel needs work is on the speed of the interface. review_title: About a tie with Fire Stick
review_text: (I have reviewed the Fire Stick, since I have purchased both, unable to make up my mind which one I wanted for my 2 smart TVs). This device has performed flawlessly, although it helps I have the best available residential internet service (Cox Gigablast), cable modem (Arris SB8200) and wifi mesh router (Orbi, with 3 satellites). Comparing the remote to the one sold with the Fire Stick, I prefer the layout of buttons on the Fire Stick. The voice button on the Roku remote is hard to find, located in the middle among other buttons. And the volume buttons are tiny, located on the side where it is too easy to hit the mute button inadvertently. The large, conspicuous buttons for Netflix, Disney, Hulu, and Sling are nice (since I subscribe to 3 of these services), but are redundant since most of us prefer voice. Both remotes badly need buttons that light up in the night, similar to the Cox Contour remote I just gave up. Highly recommend either Stick; you might select based on slight differences of contracted streaming services and whether you need without extra cost an HDMI extension adapter (I did with my Samsung), which for now only comes with the Fire Stick.

review_title: Decent UX marred by performance and compatibility issues
review_text: Well, after a week of troubleshooting attempts, I've thrown in the towel and decided to return this, my first Roku product. While the UX is quite good (fast, reasonably well designed), and the feature set is appealing, there were two problems for me that led to this outcome:1. Surround sound issue due to lack of Dolby Digital support for older equipmentDuring my fall into the Roku support forum rabbit hole, I learned that there are two varieties of Dolby surround: Dolby Digital (DD) and Dolby Digital Plus (DD+). Providers such as Disney+ provide surround audio in DD+, but not DD; my older receiver (a Denon) can't decode the former, so I only get stereo audio from those programs. Competing streaming devices apparently can convert DD+ to DD in these cases, but the Roku can't (in spite of what the available device settings would lead you to believe). Comments in the forums suggest that some older Roku models can perform this conversion, and that this product used to until recent Roku updates.As a work-around, I routed the Roku through my Blu-ray player, which can process DD+ streams. Not as convenient, but not a deal-breaker on its own.2. Video stutters after rewind on Netflix, Disney +I've observed this problem on Netflix and Disney +, on multiple shows. (I hadn't tried any other services.) Typically, when I play a program for the first time, motion is pretty smooth; no noticeable artifacts. However, If I rewind the program a bit and then play, I see a choppiness that seems to be a frozen frame every 1/4 sec. or so. This is most noticeable on pans and slow zooms. (Some might describe this as a stutter.) The effect is sufficiently severe to make this a deal-breaker for me.I went through the troubleshooting steps covered on the support forums, with no success. I also have a Comcast X1 box with Netflix; I tested the same shows on that device, but could not reproduce the problem there. So it sure seems that the problem lies with the Roku.So, given all of the above, I'm giving up on this product. Customers with more recent gear might not encounter the problems I did, but for others this would be something to consider before choosing this as your streaming device.

review_text: I bought this because I don't have an HD receiver in my bedroom and I want to stream sports in HD quality to my HD TV in my bedroom. My family used to be able to watch sports on the one TV in the house with an HD receiver, but we have had family members move in and completely ruin the experience. I have used Chromecast for years, and there have been so many issues with it but it generally worked well enough. But since football season started, I have been especially frustrated with a lack of smooth streaming, and I knew I couldn't go through a whole football season struggling with streaming issues. To top it off, we switched several months ago from slow DSL to a much faster ISP, and we should not be having the same types of streaming issues at all...but we were, at least with respect to Chromecast performance.So, I decided to look up Roku and I was curious about what channel apps were available. I read that any channel that has an app would be available on Roku, so that was good enough for me and I purchased it. It has worked great...very few streaming issues at all, and the little bit that exist clear up pretty fast and then you have a smooth streaming experience.A few problems, though, most of which have been fixed/worked around at this time:1) The BTN2Go app does not play live TV. It says, "This video is currently unavailable. Please check back later" every time. Thankfully, you can watch the Big Ten Network through the Fox Sports app.2) It takes a little too long for each app to start up. This is pretty annoying when you're trying to flip back and forth between various games.3) Roku does not, in fact, have every app associated with streaming live TV. If you want to watch CBS and CBS Sports Network games, it's pretty hard to do so because Roku does not have the actual CBS Sports app. They have this crappy, worthless CBS Sports HQ app that does not show any games, and they have the CBS app that expects you to pay monthly to stream CBS programming. Yet, the CBS Sports app and the CBS Sports site both let you stream SEC games and games on CBS Sports Network (usually AAC and military academy games) for free. I spent hours on Saturday trying to figure out how I can get around this issue and finally figured out how to mirror my laptop screen to Roku. But I really had to dig around online for this info. I really would rather not have to mirror my laptop at all for games; I'd like the real CBS Sports app to be available on Roku.4) It's pretty annoying how every time you want to use an app for the first time that requires your TV cable subscription info, you have to go to your phone or PC/laptop and go to some link to get access.5) I did have an issue with the Roku connecting and disconnecting repeatedly when I first hooked it up and went through set up. Once I reset the stick, unplugged it and plugged it back in and went through setup again, this issue was resolved.--After getting these issues figured out, except for the slow app load times, there's nothing wrong with Roku at all--it's the best $60 or $70 you'll ever spend. Great video quality and great performance. It has saved my football season, and probably my basketball, tennis, softball, etc, seasons, as well. It works so well that it's easy to leave it on and stream up my internet bandwidth usage because I forget it's not the actual cable. It just streams seamlessly.

review_title: Great reception at a distance from wireless access point
review_text: I always read reviews, check out review sites like TechRadar... After reading many glowing reviews on the Roku Streaming Stick+, I decided it was worth a go. Installation was extremely easy. I live in a 3000+ sq ft house, and the wireless access point is downstairs on the other side of the house. The Roku stick picked it up immediately and has yet to drop it. After 2 weeks and nearly flawless performance, I pulled the plug on my provider. I don't miss 800+ channels (many redundant) and my nearly $300 monthly bill. The kids one demand was a TV channel that rhymes with 'Rick'. So for the cost of wireless, an Indoor antenna (sold in a green box) for local channels, and minimal subscription costs to 3 streaming services (First letters N, H and P, in case I'm not supposed to mention names), I get everything the family wants and only a wireless bill. I advise providing power to the stick via AC power vs USB. In my case, every time the TV power was turned off, power to the stick was removed, and it had to go through a reboot cycle next time the TV was turned on. Doesn't happen on AC power. Gets a bit hot, but nothing out of the ordinary. And unless I have to change the TV Input source or TV channels to select signals provided by the Indoor Antenna, the Roku remote controls my TV power, volume and allows me to select programs via voice input. For the cost, a GREAT bargain! Goodbye, cable TV.

review_title: I brought my rating from 4 to 3
review_text: I brought my rating from 4 to 3.My main criticism concerns the remote. It has only very limited functions and there is no performant alternative to be found on Amazon or elsewhere. Therefore, the Roku remote cannot take control of the TV sleep function or the image and sound settings. Neither does it allow to mute the sound, if you can believe that. I have no alternative than to juggle with 2 remotes.Technically, the remote doesn't work well. It often becomes unresponsive while the batteries are still good. When this happens, I can wait a minute or two, and if this isn't enough, take the batteries out and back in, turn the TV off, and if this still doesn't work, unplug the stick, reset the router... It happens more and more often - at least once every hour when I zap between channels.Finally, there are buffering problems and frequent sound-image coordination problems, which do not exist on my Roku Ultra.This stick wasn't the great buy I initially thought.

review_text: Like all products on Amazon, reviews are all over the place on this Roku streaming stick. Some say it was hard to set up, some say they got a faulty unit. I had no issues at all. I guess some USB ports don't supply enough power to run a Roku but the Roku will tell you if it has the power to work and my Samsung tv was able to do this. Set up was very simple, just follow the on screen directions. Someone also said the remote would not control a sound bar so I was ready to use a separate remote to control the volume. The remote connected automatically to my TV AND sound bar! My sound bar is an older model and is plugged into the optical audio out. When I hit the Roku's power button the TV comes on and so does the sound bar. Volume is also supported! Our TV is a pre 2016 75 inch Samsung smart TV with a lot of apps like Netflix but didn't support YouTube TV which we are going to use after we dump DirectTV which is costing in the $150 range now. It's available on the Roku. I upgraded our router at the same time as ours was getting a little long in the tooth. Bottom line is Roku is easy to set up, simple to navigate and has lots of great features, some of which aren't even listed in the description. On the fence? Buy it!

review_title: Remote Drains Batteries when USB powered
review_text: I've had many Rokus for a good number of years, but needed 2 of them to put behind tvs without having a cable hanging down. This is why we I purchased 2 sticks.Plugging this device into the USB on the back of a TV (or any powersource that isn't always on like a switched outlet) causes the batteries in the remote to run dry in less than a week (without even being used!)While this is an engineering flaw that could probably be sorted out with a firmware update, my low review comes from Roku choosing to ignore this issue for years, and continuing to give its customers the runaround. They haven't owned the issue or worked on a fix...instead just directing customers to simply plug the USB into a power outlet instead of their TV.If you're planning on plugging this device into the USB power on the back of your TV, and aren't 100% that your USB stays powered when your TV is off...then best to find a different solution than this.Roku wants this device to always be on...that way it can monitor your entire network and sell the information advertisers...so don't expect a fix for this!

review_text: These are my first Rokus, bought two at once, and overall, I’m pleased with the outcome, but there is a problem with the remotes eating up the battery charge.Installation: 2 large TVs up close against the wall. The Roku Stick goes to an HDMI port, and for the older of my TVs, this port is at the back middle of the TV, not off more to the side. When plugging the Roku stick into this HDMI port, it is sticking out perpendicular to the wall, and sticking out too far for the TV to be put back close to the wall. (The Roku stick is a few inches long.) Problem solved with UGREEN HDMI Extension Cable 4K HDMI Extender Male to Female Compatible for . . . Roku TV Stick, 1.5 ft., at Amazon of course. So, the Roku Stick hangs from an extension behind the TV, not a problem.Setup and activation: Entered a couple of items, went so fast and smooth I can’t remember much about it anymore. Wireless reception excellent but I wasn’t expecting problems here. Watching mostly the local PBS station’s “Passport”, Netflix, Amazon Prime.Remote: Reason for only 3 out of 5 stars. It’s easy to use and controls the TV power and volume without a second remote needed. However, as also mentioned in a previous review, there’s an issue with the remotes eating up the charge of the batteries. After only about 5 weeks, the first remote needed a battery change. The second remote needed a battery change after 7 weeks, and these were Duracell batteries.

The manual states that you can order it for free and it arrives within a few days. But why is it NOT INCLUDED to begin with? Also, the part that they provided does not even work. I dont know if it fails to convert HDCP 2.2 through the extender, but the Roku stick would not get detected by my TV as an HDMI source. I created my own extender using a regular HDMI cable and attached an HDMI coupler to it, and that worked well. This is the reason why I gave it 4 stars. review_text: Of the various streaming devices that we have, this is our favorite. It's very affordable, it's small, it was easy to physically hook up, and easy to set up and use. It's got an extensive list of popular apps, as well as some apps we've never heard of that we plan to experiment with. Aside from the great variety of apps, what makes it a favorite for us is the remote. It fits very comfortably in the hand, the buttons have a solid tactile feel, and the button functions are sensible. There's a volume control for the TV that's very convenient, but unfortunately it doesn't have a mute button. The primary reason we didn't rate this Roku device 5 stars, however, has to do with the prolonged difficulty that we had to get the advertised $50 Sling credit from our new Roku account for a new Sling account. Roku and Sling repeatedly pointed responsibility to each other. After a week of attempting to get the credit and spending over 8 hours on the phone with both Roku and Sling, Roku ultimately rejected our claim for the credit even though we are new subscribers to both! I subsequently requested a return authorization from Amazon. After a short cooling off period, however, we decided not to give up and I'm happy to say we figured it out.

review_title: Great streaming player at a good price
review_text: I've had the Roku Streaming Stick+ for about a week now and I am very impressed with it. I have used a Sony Blu-Ray player with streaming capabilities for about thee years, but it has quirks and the software is rarely updated. It's usability had become so poor that I began checking into other players such as Roku. I almost bought the same model at Costco but decided to see if Amazon's prices was better - which it was, to the tune of $10, and with Prime I got it delivered the next day.Installation was quick and easy, as was setup. There are literally hundreds of additional streaming channels, both pay and free, to download in addition to those pre-installed on the device. Since I bought it, we have used it every day almost to the exclusion of my cable subscription and our DVD/Blu-Ray library. It's not only the selection of material, but also the quality of the picture (I'm running 1080p on a 60" plasma TV) and audio. There's never any pause for buffering like the Sony player would do on the same internet connection, no skips or dropped frames. The controls are simple and easy to use, even for my wife who's often hopeless with technology. I'm very pleased with my Roku and can't wait to upgrade to a 4k TV so I can take advantage of the device's capabilities at that resolution. I would buy it again and recommend it to anyone who wants a quality streaming device.

review_text: UPDATE: As you can see from my original review, I was very happy with Roku after my first purchase. The only fix I've found is to unplug the unit, plug it back in, take out the batteries, and pair the remote with the TV again. Nope. I've contacted Roku again. If they're not able to offer a real fix, I'm returning the stick. This appears to be a known issue (read the one star reviews). Why in the world isn't Roku fixing this?!ORIGINAL REVIEW: I've been using an Amazon Fire Stick for several years, and, though I love Amazon, I was never totally happy with it as a media device. It was very limited and balky, and in recent months it needed to be rebooted every time I wanted to use it.I'd heard good things about Roku, so I grabbed this at a great deal. It works like a dream! review_text: First off, I want to be clear that activation of the Roku device is free. Purchasing the device is the only money you pay to Roku. If you have somehow end up on a website claiming that you have to pay them an activation fee or an upgrade fee just to be able to use your Roku device then you have navigated to the wrong address and it is a scam. What you do have to pay for, if you choose to do so, is any of the paid subscription streaming services you want. Some services require a paid subscription and some don't. To name a few: Watching basic YouTube (the same ones you watch for free on your phone, tablet, or computer), Tubi TV, Pluto TV, and hoopla (if available through your public library) are all free of charge. Netflix, Amazon Video, CBS All Access, YouTube TV, and Apple TV+ charge a monthly fee, but that has nothing to do with whether or not you use a Roku device to access their content.We bought a TCL Roku TV a couple years ago and, between Netflix and Prime, found that we weren't watching cable television anymore. So we downgraded to internet-only service through our cable provider and got this stick for our bedroom TV.Unlike some of the less expensive Roku offerings, the remote that comes with this one does both TV power and volume, so as long as you're getting all your content through Roku (and never need to switch inputs to, say, cable/satellite/antenna service or a DVD player) you don't need to have a separate TV remote. I was surprised the remote doesn't have a mute button, though. Our TCL Roku TV's remote had such a button. So if you're a heavy user of the mute button you may find that this does not in fact save you from needing a separate TV remote. I'm also a little troubled that our Roku TV, which we bought new only about two years ago, doesn't support Apple TV+. This particular streaming stick does support it. But it seems like a couple years is way too early for a streaming device to be even starting to creep into obsolescence. I have no interest in buying a new Roku stick every few years, and hope this isn't a sign of what's to come.If you have a home server for media, be aware that the Roku Media Player app is terrible. It only supports a fairly minimal set of formats, requires a UPnP/DLNA server and doesn’t support a simple SMB file share, and it just seems a little buggy sometimes. People would tell you the correct thing to do is to install Plex, and they’re probably right, but seriously can’t I just play files that are available over my network? Any computer or smartphone could do it. We desperately need a VLC app for Roku.It's also clear that the Roku stick has no idea whether the TV is on or off. This means that (unless the Roku is being petted by a USB port on the TV that turns off when the TV does) if you just push the power button on the remote in the middle of watching something, it will keep playing--and perhaps even advance automatically to the next show. This means you'll lose your place in a series and, perhaps more importantly, will consume more power and data. So remember to stop playback when you turn off the TV. Or get one of those power strips that automatically turns off accessories when the master device turns off. (Or buy a Roku TV instead of a separate TV and Roku stick--but remember my comment above about sliding into obscelescence.)If you're looking for free entertainment, there are some options but you probably won't find them up to par with paid cable TV or perhaps even with free over-the-air TV. Tubi has some content, including a "Not on Netflix" section. Pluto TV is okay--it has a lot of channels, but they're largely underwhelming. There's a local news "channel" that in our case gives us content for the nearest big city, an hour away, rather than our actual local news stations. The Roku Channel occasionally has a movie worth watching. Your public library may offer some content through Hoopla as well. So there are some free options, but you're unlikely to be completely satisfied without some form of paid entertainment.

review_text: I bought this product in June of 2021 to test it out. I told everyone I knew that the Roku was superior for a variety of reasons and even thought about switching out my firesticks for more Rokus.I use the Rokus of three of my TVs with several severals including ATT TV, Disney, Prime, Netflix, etc.About three months ago, after and update, I began to experience several issues with the Roku product. Sometimes the audio begins to lag, expecially on ATT TV recorded programs. On other services, sometimes the audio with drop out completely or suddenly become very loud, clipping the audio.Some other reviews have said that these problems are with the audio source, BUT I DO NOT HAVE THESE PROBLEMS ON ANY OF THE TELEVISIONS THAT USE THE AMAZON FIRESTICK.I finally was able to talk with someone at Roku back in July about the issue. Roku has several audio settings and they suggested that I try a different setting(s). I did this for a while and it seemed to work. However, the problems never completely went away. I have tried various audio settings to no avail. Again, I do not have these issues with the Amazon Firestick, so I do not believe it is solely the fault of the source.I have tried over the last few weeks to talk to someone at Roku, but I have found ZERO phone support. I have checked their knowledge base to no avail.So, while this was one my favorite product, I am now about to replace them if I cannot find a resolution. It is too frustrating and painful to try to adjust the audio settings every other day. The total combination of audio settings to be tried are greater than 20.This product has gone from being my favorite to one I am seriously thinking of replacing on all of my TVs.

review_title: Actually Works as Well as Promised, Better Than Our Govt!
review_text: So far this year, we've ordered four streaming + sticks for 4 in-house and one RV usage. The sticks work great. Long range RF remotes mean I can irritate the Wife Unit by changing streaming channels from two rooms away. These are our first streamers and they are light years ahead of the two Samsung "smart" TVs. Near instantaneous response to channel changes as measured against our zzzz response to channel changes from DISH TV. The voice recognition works about 80% of the time. That is good since I search for some weird stuff when going down the you tube video rabbit hole. They are all 4 happy with our regular 50 MB AT&T wifi and work even down to <13 MB/sec on 2.4/5 GHz after the signal goes through a wifi extender which isn't really needed (used for jamming neighbor's way-over-powered wifi). No pausing and plenty of buffering. They struggle a little (intermittant signal loss outrunning the buffering) with the campground wifi since it is always overloaded but it is not really a current problem since CA "science" says the virus can jump, from one campsite 150' to another, and has closed our campgrounds. We really like being able to get real news and grand-punkin programming in higher res than the compressed DISH signals. If there are any minuses, it would be that I accidentally keep hitting the 4 direct-tune buttons on the bottom two rows of the remote. We don't subscribe to any of the pay-to-streamers there. After the warranty is gone maybe I'll open up the remotes and disable the buttons. We were not able to get a ROKU streaming channel to work through ROKU even with their help once. They tried but couldn't get it to work even through the designers of the channel. We recommend the ROKU streaming stick+. So far, no stick failures amongst four of them. Be sure to order the free little HDMI extension asap from the site in the instructions with your serial #. It is great stress relief for the HDMI connection to the TV. We power two of the sticks off of the USBs on the TVs and two of the sticks with their USB wall wart power supply. No diff except for about 30 second ROKU reset after turning on TV if using TV USB connection for power. No, nobody compensated me for this spew. We like our ROKUs!

review_text: Really good product. Had a little trouble with Roku customer service initially. The extension cable for the A/C adapter was defective; it would lose power randomly. After diagnosing there was nothing wrong with the product itself I attempted to procure a replacement cable from Roku. The customer representative wanted me to send the entire unit back to Roku and they would send me a replacement unit. When I insisted that I only needed the cable and not the whole unit replace I was told I had to send the whole unit back which was frustrating. Ended up keeping everything and just throwing the cable away. No problems to date since. Makes it a lot nicer to stream on our tv instead of a computer. There are a lot of apps available for different channels. One thing that is frustrating though is there is no antenna app built into the streaming stick. author: Barbara Evensen

review_title: Roku TV and Roku sticks are not at all the same thing! Read carefully!
review_text: I have to say that I am disappointed in this purchase. I did fairly extensive research before deciding to buy the Roku Streaming Stick+, comparing it to Apple TV, Playstation Vue, Amazon Fire and others. I even read the Roku website and blog that says the following:BackgroundJust like your smartphone has an “app store” for installing new applications, you can access the Roku Channel Store on your Roku streaming player or Roku TV™ to add new “channels”. Channels are applications for your television, popular channels include Netflix, YouTube, Hulu, VUDU and HBO GO. Additionally, current generation Roku devices include access to The Roku Channel, which features hit movies and TV at no cost to you.Do I have to pay for channels?Although some channels must be purchased or require a paid subscription, many others allow you to watch movies and TV shows for free.Which channels allow me to watch movies and TV shows?There are many channels that offer movies and TV shows including popular choices like Netflix, Google Play, Vudu, FandangoNOW and Hulu.Search Movies & TV shows in the Roku Channel Store.Are there channels that allow me to watch live or local TV?Yes, there are live broadcast channels like ABC, NBC, CBS, HGTV and Fox. In addition, some cable/satellite companies are creating Roku streaming channels that allow you to access all or most of the channels you get through your cable subscription without having a separate cable box (e.g. Spectrum TV, Comcast Xfinity, DIRECTV NOW).If you have Roku TV, you can also connect an antenna to access live and local broadcast TV over the air.I got the distinct impression that I'd be able to watch my live and local broadcast TV via the Roku system. Wrong. Turns out that the Roku stick does not have an antenna slot, and the Roku channels provide "live" news that is actually not live. It's an amalgam of news recorded throughout the day and then recycled throughout the day on various channels. Further, when I tried to watch Saturday Night Live, I could only access archived Saturday Night Live episodes, or buy a separate subscription for the show. Hey, I'm used to watching it live, for free, over my HDTV antenna. So, I ended up switching back to my antenna. The only way to actually get what was advertised is to not buy the Roku stick, but, rather, to buy a Roku TV with an antenna slot that allows live and local broadcast TV to be processed via the Roku TV system, including pause and replay. Ya gotta read the fine-print!The only reason I'm still giving Roku 2 stars is because, in its own right, with all the caveats I've mentioned, it's not too bad. I'm hoping I can get used to having both the Roku stick and the HDTV antenna to serve my needs.Update May 27, 2018: my Roku stick stopped working. Not sure what happened. Power surge? Really don't know. But, after calling customer support and going through the usual "Is it plugged in?... Have you tried a different outlet?..." they finally gave me a return authorization, so now I'm waiting for a replacement. Sheesh.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2018

I am now very concerned with long term longevity with these units. Of the 7, I now have pretty serious issues with 2 sticks. One has intermittent wifi connection issues that essentially began over nite. I've moved it around, rebooted, changed feeds, rebooted the router and wifi all to no avail. The second stick seems to have a problem with the HDMI plug on the stick itself. I started seeing some kind of copy protection warnings the requires a repower to clear. Both sticks are in our condo and have been used for roughly 4 months. To top it off, the 3rd condo stick is also now beginning to act it little odd while booting up - strange screen messages, etc. Again, a reboot seems to clear things out. I contacted Roku customer service and am getting a bit of run around. Before you buy this, be aware that there seems to be hardware issues that will arise.

review_title: Great upgrade with an odd hardware choice
review_text: I have been a ROKU user for years and already own two "base" units. I bought the stick mainly for travel. The performance on this unit is great. Menus are zippy, video looks clean. All in all great things. The main problem I have with this unit - and the reason for the 2-star rating - is their choice of power connector.For some inexplicable reason in 2021 they chose to use a USB MINI connector. That wasn't a typo: A USB MINI connector from the year 2000. While the entire world has standardized on either USB-C or Micro USB Roku decided it was a good idea to bring back the Mini connector. It boggles my mind that this choice was made. I can't think of a device in the past ten years which was released with only a USB MINI. Given that in my road kit I have nothing but USB micro and USB-C it's a big deal for a travel unit. It means I have to take the provided special USB Mini cable with me everywhere or load up on Mini adapters again. This is just completely, utterly wrong for a unit whose primary function is travel.While the performance upgrades are nice the power connector choice means this will not be a part of my road kit sorry to say. Very disappointed that they went this way for a travel-centric unit.

review_title: Severe Audio Issues with AVR Surround Sound Systems
review_text: When I first purchased the Roku Streaming Stick+, I thought it was a nice improvement over my 1st Gen Amazon FireTV Stick with the Roku being able to search multiple apps for specific movies and television while the Firestick pushed Amazon products. Others have complained that the Roku interface looks dated but I found it to be familar and easy to navigate with a quick response time and very little lag. But that is where the positives end for the Roku.I connected the Roku Streaming Stick+ to my Yamaha RX-679 surround sound receiver via HDMI and it played fine at first. But then I started getting frequent, sporadic audio drops where the center channel would simply fade out and the volume would drop so low that it became inaudible. It would stay low for several minutes and then return to normal before repeating the audio issue. I tried numerous app updates, system restarts, system resets, updated the firmware on the Roku and the Yamaha receiver, switched HDMI ports and HDMI cables but nothing resolved the issue.Out of desperation, I returned the Roku Streaming Stick+ to Amazon and purchased a Roku Ultra hoping that would resolve the issue but it didn't. I contacted the Roku support team and listed all of the pertinent details in my original message before receiving a response that seemed to indicate most of my original message had went unread because I was being asked questions that I had already answered. I answered those same questions again and Roku support told me to disconnect the Roku from my AVR and connect it directly to the television, completely bypassing my surround sound system and just using the built-in television speakers.A quick internet search shows that Roku has had audio issues with surround sound systems as far back as Roku 3 and as recently as the Roku Premiere+ so I told the Roku support team to address the issues with their audio coding instead of asking customers to find subpar workarounds. After doing so, the Roku support team claimed that my Yamaha receiver was to blame, marked the claim as being "resolved" and closed the ticket.I had the FireTV Stick, a PS4 and an Xbox One all connected to the Yamaha receiver via HDMI and all of those devices played through my 7.1 surround sound system flawlessly. So it is obvious that Roku would rather place the fault within other components instead of taking responsibility for its own faulty software.My advice is to stay away from Roku if you have any kind of surround sound system. A sound bar may work with the Roku but it seems that audio systems with multiple audio channels will have problems with the Roku software and the Roku support team is completely useless in resolving these issues.

review_title: The Roku Channel now showing hundreds of free movies & Locast has free CBS/NBC/FOX/ABC/PBS
review_text: I've been a Roku user for years,including several different models. Roku has recently released The Roku Channel,which has hundreds of free movies.It is ad supported.And now Locast app gives you free local broadcast stations CBS,NBC,FOX,ABC and PBS.Locast now offers local TV network broadcasts for New York,Boston,Chicago,Houston,Dallas,Denver areas and plans to add many more cities.This means many folks will no longer need antennas to watch local networks for free. Roku has just about every app you can imagine (YouTube/Pandora/Netflix/Amazon/Hulu/HBO Now) and thousands of more apps in many different categories.This Roku Streaming Stick PLUS does have more advanced WiFi antenna than the regular Streaming Stick.Here are some points to consider when deciding on which model of Roku to buy:1)If you need to connect by WiFi in a room far away from your WiFi router,I would recommend the Roku Streaming Stick PLUS or Roku Ultra.2)If you have a 4K TV,I would recommend the Roku Ultra or Roku Streaming Stick PLUS.The Premiere 2018 model also plays 4K.3)To search for content using your voice,go with either the Streaming Stick,Streaming Stick PLUS or Ultra.All 3 of these models also have a remote that can control the power and volume on a TV.There is also a Roku app for Android & iPhone/iPad that lets you use your smartphone/tablet to control any Roku device and use your phone/tablet on-screen keyboard for searches.4)If you want a wired ethernet connection,go with the Roku Ultra.5)If you want to connect to an old TV with RCA/Composite audio/video jacks,you will need the Express PLUS6)The Express & Premiere 2018 models have a remote where it has to be pointed at the device,unlike the other Roku models.7)If you are only going to buy one Roku device,I would recommend the Roku Ultra.The Ultra has many unique features that the other Roku models don't such as:-Gaming buttons to play video games-Remote finder to find a lost remote control-Ethernet port for a wired connection-Micro SD card slot-USB Port-Night listening mode (this lowers the volume of loud,explosive sounds and raises the volume of soft sounds like whispers.Very useful!)-Headphone jack on the remote for listening without disturbing othersBottom Line:You can now get a Roku device to replace your cable TV box & service or to replace an antenna for free local network TV.And of course you can create your own custom TV experience that simply is not possible with cable or antenna TV.

author: Madi

review_title: Easy setup, clean interface, but no control over data usage
review_text: This was my 1st Roku device, and my 2nd streaming "stick" (the other one being a Fire TV stick 2019 generation). I had read articles comparing the 2 and thought Roku might be better. It was nicer in some ways, but lacking in one important feature area - data saving and data monitoring.Pros:-Easy setup (about the same as my Fire TV Stick)-Clean interface (less ads and overall easier than Fire TV Stick)-Lots of apps/channels (about the same as Fire)-Xfinity Stream beta app works better on Roku than on Fire right nowCons:-Had to find special link to signup for Roku without giving them a credit card. I pay for my streaming services by signing up directly with Netflix, Disney+ etc and didn't want Roku in the middle of that, especially just to get started and try it out. But if you like to buy a single movie "on demand" thru any Roku channel, you'd want to have a credit card on file, so maybe this wouldn't be a big deal to some.-Volume & especially the Mute buttons located on side of remote are easily clicked by accident while holding the remote in your hand-Couldn't get the Roku remote to control my TV to change the input to the right one for watching the roku-Can't install Firefox web browser for full surfing (can do this on Fire, its clunky but a nice option to have)-Can't put it into Sleep mode for low power and no data usage (Fire stick does have this)-Can't see any data usage by app/channel...Fire TV Stick allows this under Settings>Preferences>Data Monitoring. It is a nice way to see how much a particular app is using so that you can attempt to control data usage in that app's settings (or choose to watch things in the lower usage apps). i.e., Disney+ defaults to a very high streaming quality using 3-4Gb per hour. At least you can change that quality within their app to save data. But having the Fire stick show you the usage per app is a handy way to evaluate which apps are data hogs. Roku doesn't have this feature.-Can't limit the streaming quality (aka data usage) in the Roku Stick settings - there was a hidden option at one time that may have done this (Bit Rate Override). You can still get into that setting but it doesn't appear to work anymore and the Roku support forum reply is basically saying "sorry, too bad" because hidden/developer features are not intended to be supported so this isn't a bug. Jeez, that's lousy - fair point in the software world, but this was a hidden feature discussed all over the internet and used by many prior to 2019. Roku forum also suggests you should set your home router to limit the data used by the device - not all routers can do that by device, not all users can do that.So, look, I'm sure some of you will think the data usage issue isn't Roku's fault, blame your ISP for putting caps, use the features within your channels/apps to limit usage, etc. A few of our streaming svc apps/channels give you the ability to throttle the data usage with quality/bit rate settings, but most do not. I don't think its too much to ask a long-established streaming device maker to include a feature for this. And since the Amazon Fire TV Stick does this, I'm going to return this Roku and get a 2nd Fire stick when they go on sale.I did really like the cleaner interface on the Roku and wanted to like it enough that I could give one to my 70+ yr old parents, but not if I can't easily limit their data usage at the stick. Sorry Roku, you didn't earn my business.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021

And, yes, everything was filled out correctly, including the serial number. To cover all bases, I also tried applying for my “free” extension on both my iPhone and my iPad. So I’m returning the device. This was a frustrating waste of my time. Also, I have read similar complaints from other customers. Reaching someone from Roku customer service was impossible. So I can only conclude that this whole charade regarding the “free” Roku extension is intentional. Otherwise, it would be just a stupid oversight, which seems unlikely considering that Roku has set up this fake process in recognition that its devices do not fit all TV hdmi slots. A word of advice, Roku: If it doesn’t fit, simply tell the customer to return your device. That would serve them much better than this ongoing scam.
